On Tuesday July 26th 1621 hours, M/Cpl. Santiago assisted the property manager at Bethel Villa Apartments with an
apartment inspection at 402 E. 4th St Apt. C2. The inspection was requested by the property manager due to an incident that occurred
the day prior where a maintenance worker for the property reported that a black male subject brandished a handgun from his
waistband and walked into Apt C2. (30-22-51731). While the property manager was inspecting the apartment, officer Santiago
observed in plain view, a large clear plastic zip lock bag containing marijuana (38 grams) on the living room sofa, a handgun inside a
clear plastic bag on the kitchen table, and drug paraphernalia on the living room coffee table. Santiago then detained the defendant and
transported her to central for processing. The defendant also had an active warrant out of JP Court 11 for Failure to Appear. The
firearm located was a S&W 9mm handgun loaded with (15) rounds of ammunition

On May 21st, 2024 CGIC Detectives were in the area of West 26th St and North West St when they observed
Zyheen Evans, Sincere Johnson and Dhossan Whyte walking westbound on 26th St. Detectives attempted to make contact with
Zyheen at which point he immediately fled west on 26th St and into 118 W 26th St. Zyheen then exited the residence through a side
basement door and began fleeing westbound through an alley. After a brief pursuit, Zyheen was taken into custody without incident. A
search granted a search warrant for the residence. During a search of the residence detectives located and recovered one black in color
Taurus G2 Millennium with an obliterated serial number loaded with 11 rounds of 9mm ammunition, 1 spent 9mm casing, 1 round of
32 auto ammunition, and a black in color holster.
UPDATE
On May 23rd, 2024 CGIC detectives were advised the above mentioned spent casing had a NIBIN connection to 5 additional
incidents. Over the following weeks, detectives conducted an investigation into the NIBIN match at which point they were able to
apply for and were granted a search warrant in reference to 118 W 26th St.
On June 5th, 2024 CGIC detectives were conducting surveillance on 118 W 26th St in reference to this investigation at which point
Maurice Cooper, Brian Palmer, and Kaleek Brooks were observed entering the residence. During this time DOCV, Safe Streets and
Juvenile Probation began responding to the area to assist with the investigation. Moments later Maurice, Brian and Kaleek exited the
residence and began walking westbound.
CGIC detectives responded to the area of 27th and N West St where they observed Maurice, Brian, and Kaleek standing next to a
white in color Ford Fusion. A pedestrian stop was attempted at which point Maurice immediately began to flee however was taken
into custody after a foot pursuit with the assistance of DOCV and Safe Streets. Brian Palmer and Kaleek Brooks were both taken into
custody without incident. Kaleek was found to be in possession of a black in color Smith and Wesson SW99 45 caliber handgun (S/N
SAH0697) which was loaded with 3 rounds of 45 caliber ammunition.
While on scene at the pedestrian stop, surveillance observed William Brooks entering a white in color vehicle in front of 118 W 26th
St. The vehicle ultimately responded to the intersection of 27th St and West St at which point Detectives made contact with vehicle
and took William into custody regarding this investigation. A search of the vehicle was conducted which yielded negative results.
Members of CGIC, DOCV, Probation and Safe Streets responded to 118 W 26th St and executed the search warrant. During a search
of the residence, detectives located and recovered the following:
- Silver and Black in color Smith & Wesson SD9VE 9mm handgun (S/N FCY5646) which was loaded with 11 rounds of 9mm
ammunition.
- Silver and Black in color Glock 17 CO2 BBgun
- 2 unspent 9mm rounds of ammunition
William, Kaleek, Brian and Maurice were transported to Central along with the evidence. Test fire forms were submitted.
William was charged with Possession of a Firearm by Person Prohibited X 2 and Carrying Concealed Deadly Weapon. Kaleek was
charged with Possession of a Firearm/Ammo by Person Prohibited X 2 and Carrying Concealed Deadly Weapon.
Maurice was charged with Resisting Arrest and processed on his outstanding Capias’s, additional charges pending the results of DNA.
Brain was released at this time pending the results of DNA.

On Thursday January 12th 1509 hours, SCU Investigators were in the 3000 block of N. Madison St conducting an
area canvass for suspect(s) regarding a recent shooting. During the canvass, SCU observed several subjects immediately exiting the
park located at E. 30th St and N. Madison St upon the Streets Crime Vehicle approaching. SCU conducted an area canvass within the
park which yielded a firearm that was concealed in an apparent discarded jacket. During a follow up area canvass, SCU Investigators
were able to locate the subjects, later identified as Zye’l Richardson BM (06/18/2007), Jashad Helm BM (01/12/2007), Zakyse
Carter BM (11/25/2007) and Adrian Younger BM (10/23/2006) in the area of W. 29th and N. Washington Street. A pedestrian stop
was conducted and during a pat down, Zye’l Richardson was found to be in possession of a loaded black in color S&W M&P 9mm
handgun (reported stolen out of Clayton County, GA on 12/09/2021.) Jashad Helm was found to be in possession of a loaded black
in color Glock 44 .22 handgun.
SCU pursued additional investigative measures which lead to developing Defendant 3 Vincent Hodge BM (04/18/2005) as a person
of interest pertaining to the discarded firearm in the jacket. Defendant 3 was in the park playing basketball at the time of the firearm
discovery and initially denied ownership of the recovered jacket. After a brief struggle, Investigators were able to place Defendant 3
into custody. Hodge also possessed an active Capias for his arrest for criminal mischief. SCU Investigators seized the jacket and
firearm which was determined to be (1) silver in color Raven Arms model P-25 bearing serial possible #464703 which contained (3)
three rounds of .25 caliber ammunition in the magazine. SCU Investigators conducted a post-Miranda interview at Wilmington
Police HQ with Defendant 3 and his parents. During the interview, Investigators were able to obtain a confession from Hodges with
regards to possessing the firearm in the jacket. Investigators also learned of suspected North Pak gang ties.
Defendants Richardson, Helm and Hodge were charged accordingly with respective firearm charges. Zakyse Carter and Adrian
Younger were released from detention and turned over to parent/ guardians. A test fire request was submitted pertaining to all 3
firearms.

On Friday January 20th 1600 hours, SCU Investigators responded to 1213 West Ave. New Castle, DE (Superlodge)
in regards to locating (Darnell Rollins BM 06/09/04) who was actively wanted for a VOP, Strangulation, Driving Offenses as well as
being sought out by the Criminal Investigative Division as a Person of Interest in an Armed Robbery. A search warrant was applied
and granted and at approximately 1924 hours, Darnell Rollins, Leroy Brown BM 10/12/02, Jahkei Fairley BM 12/06/03 and Ashley
Peacock BF 05/31/87 exited the motel room and were all taken into custody without incident. Investigators conducted a search of the
hotel room and located a loaded:
• Taurus G3C 9mm bearing serial number # ACA477217 (1) round in chamber and (12) rounds in the magazine
• Polymer 80 9mm firearm with an extended magazine containing (27) 9mm rounds.
Investigators preserved Instagram footage of Rollins possessing what is believed to be the above Taurus firearm and a Polymer 80.
However, Rollins will not be charged with the Polymer 80 firearm (Pending DNA results). Rollins was charged with PFBPP Gun and
Ammo and processed on his capias. Leroy Brown and Ashley Peacock consented to their DNA being taken. A search warrant was
drafted for Rollins and Fairley.
Investigators executed a 3rd JP Court 11 search warrant on 1705 Pine Street which is Rollins listed residence as well as where
Emmanuel Lambert has been staying prior to his domestic arrest. The search warrant yielding negative results.
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Friday April 29th 1614 hours, officers were dispatched and responded to the 2100 block of N Pine St in reference
to a person with a gun. As officers arrived, they encountered a large group of people running north out of 2100 block of Pine St. A
bystander provided the officers with the description of a victim who was believed to have been shot. The officers were able to locate
the victim, Grady Snell BM 07/06/89, standing in front of 2115 N Pine St suffering from a gunshot wound to the left arm. While
canvassing the area, officers observed a firearm in a red Nissan Altima which was parked in front of 2119 N Pine St. A bystander
advised that the suspect had run into 2115 N Pine St following the shooting. After making contact with the suspect’s mother, officers were able to have the suspect, Michael Carpenter, exit the residence and they took him into custody without incident. Preliminary investigation revealed that the victim and suspect were arguing over money when the suspect brandished a firearm and shot the victim in the arm. Evidence collected from the scene, the vehicle, and the residence consisted of a 9mm Ruger handgun, a loaded 9mm handgun magazine, a box of 9mm ammunition, and a spent 9mm casing.

On Spetember 18, 2025, at approximately 1358 hours, WPD officers were dispatched to a shooting in the area of 2nd and
Dupont St. The victim was identified as Clarence Jarman. Please see 30-25-066796 for more details on the shooting case.
Officers quickly identified a suspect vehicle, as well as Travis Norton (08/10/2001) as a suspect. At approximately 1421 officers on scene
observed the vehicle and attempted to stop it, where it soon fled. The vehicle was stopped in the area of 1399 Oak St. Driver, Jerlysa
Williams (01/31/1996) and Norton were removed from the vehicle. A search of the vehicle yielded the recovery of a Smith and Wesson
SD9VE (SN #FZM5219) 9mm handgun. Norton was transported to Central and charged accordingly.

On January 17th, 2024, at approximately 2133 hours Wilmington Police patrol officers responded to the 1100 block
of West 3rd Street in reference to a ShotSpotter notification for 4 rounds. Upon arrival officers located 4 spent 9mm shell casings
directly in front of 1106 West 3rd Street. The surveillance footage depicted the following: Suspect 1- A black male wearing a grey in
color zip up jacket/hoodie and black pants with a white stripe down the side Suspect 2- A heavyset black male suspect wearing a black
hooded sweatshirt with a distinct logo on the left chest, black in color sweatpants with a white stripe, black in color sneakers. While
observing the video footage of this incident this said Suspect 1 appeared to enter and exit 1106 W. 3rd Street and begin to possibly
argue with unknown individuals in a white in color Nissan sedan unknown model. During the possible argument, the subject removed
a firearm concealed on his person, open the rear car door, and discharged several rounds at the individuals inside of the said vehicle.
The vehicle then immediately fled the area at a high rate of speed. As the vehicle is seen leaving the area Suspect 1 can be seen giving
the firearm to Suspect 2 who discharges additional rounds from the handgun in the direction of the said vehicle. Following the
shooting, Suspect 1 and Suspect 2 can be seen reentering 1106 West 3rd Street.
Through the course of this investigation, the suspects were identified as follows: Suspect 1- Marlen Cisney BM 02/05/2004 Suspect
2- Marcell Johnson-Chapman BM 09/09/2008 It was discovered that Marlen Cisney and Marcell Johnson-Chapman are brothers
residing at 1106 West 3rd Street. On 1/25/24, CGIC investigators began monitoring Marlen Cisney’s location, at which point he was
observed exiting 1106 West 3rd Street and was taken into custody without incident during a vehicle stop. After Marlen Cisney was
taken into custody, Detective Shea authored a search warrant for the listed residence, which was executed by members of CID, CGIC,
and USD. While officers were gaining entry into the front of the residence, Patrolman Gordy observed a handgun being discarded
from a rear window. Marcell Johnson-Chapman and Marquis Johnson-Cisney (BMNH 4/10/05) were located inside the residence and
taken into custody. Marquis Johnson-Cisney was discovered to be an additional brother of Marlen and Marcell. During a search of the
residence, a Luger P38 9mm handgun was located in the rear of the property. Additionally, clothing evidence relating to the shots
fired incident was located inside the residence. Officers then executed an additional search warrant for 704 West 31st Street, which
was listed as an additional address for Marlen. During this search, a Ruger P95 9mm handgun was located. Marlen, Macell, and
Marquis were all transported to Wilmington Police Headquarters for processing. The handguns were submitted to FSU along with a
test fire form. Detective Shea authored and executed DNA search warrants for Marcell and Marquis in reference to a firearm
investigation.

On Friday November 18th 1457 hours, SCU Investigators were in the 100 block of N. Harrison Street when they
observed a vehicle illegally parked by a fire hydrant. SCU Investigators made contact with the vehicle and observed it was occupied
by the defendant Michael Kinlaw BM 05/28/1994 who was sitting in the driver seat. Upon making contact with the defendant, SCU
Officers smelled a strong odor of marijuana emanating from inside the vehicle. The defendant was removed from the vehicle and
patted down for officer safety. The defendant was found to be in possession of 7.6 grams of marijuana on his person. A search of the
vehicle was conducted which revealed (2) two baggies of marijuana weighing a total of 16 grams as well as a partially burnt marijuana
blunt. Inside the trunk of the vehicle, Investigators located a loaded (Glock Model 23 .40 Caliber Firearm which contained (10) ten
.40 caliber rounds in the magazine. Next to the firearm an extended magazine was located containing (18) eighteen .40 caliber
rounds all items were concealed within clothing. The serial # BFTD436 was checked locally and NCIC and negative.

On Monday October 24th 0019 hours, C Platoon Officers were dispatched to 821 N. Market St (Chelsea Tavern) in
reference to a person with a gun complaint. Officers made contact with the victim who advised that he was smoking a cigarette outside
of Chelsea Tavern when the defendant (Michael Lowe) walked passed him, displayed a firearm and stated that he was going to smack
him with it. The victim then stated that Lowe walked away northbound on Market St. Officers located the defendant who as open
carrying in front of 116 W. 9th St. Officers removed a black in color Glock Gen 17 9mm (#BUNN442) firearm loaded with 15 rounds
of 9mm ammunition from Lowe’s hip holster and took Lowe into custody. Post Miranda, Lowe stated that he was inside Chelsea
Tavern and had 2 to 3 drinks and that he did not threaten anyone. Lowe advised that he was also calling the police on the victim;
however he was not able to specify what the victim said or did to him. Lowe was in possession of the firearm while under the
influence and charged accordingly.

On December 2, 2025, at approximately 1030 hours, members of Safe Streets executed an administrative search warrant for probationer, and actively wanted individual, Leshaun Bradley (09/27/2005) at the residence of 1902 Washington St. With the
assistance of Probation, WPD Safe Streets executed the warrant and where they located one black in color Glock 20 10mm (SN#CCCC722) loaded with six rounds of ammunition. Bradley was taken into custody without incident, he was transported back to Central, where he was charged accordingly.

On Wednesday June 29th 2351 hours, A Platoon Officers Wilkers & Bond were in the area of 11th & Spruce Streets
when they observed a vehicle utilize oncoming traffic lanes to pass another motor vehicle that was on the roadway. Officers
performed a motor vehicle stop and made contact with the sole occupant (Nathaniel Wells), who was exhibiting clear and obvious
signs of nervousness. During the stop, officers learned the Wells’ PA driver’s license was suspended and asked Wells to step out of
the vehicle. The defendant then placed the vehicle into drive and fled southbound on Spruce St. Officers attempted to pursue to
vehicle with negative results. Later in the shift, 16-Adam performed a follow up at 611 E. 8th St, which was an address that Wells
provided during a previous arrest. Wells was located at the residence and taken into custody. A search warrant was granted and
executed at the residence where officers recovered the following items:
• S&W 9mm handgun (#TBU5632) loaded with 11 rounds
• 29 rounds of 9mm ammunition
• 37 bags (0.259 grams) of Heroin stamped “27/30”
• 71 grams of Marijuana
• $1,030 USC
• Drug paraphernalia

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On June 3, 2025, at approximately 1903 hours, CGIC Detectives, along with Officers Mann, Marino, Shea, and Coffiey were working the 29P detail. While on patrol in the 2200 block of North Locust St, they observed a group of subjects on the western side of the street. During the time, Detectives observed Nashir Harris (04/22/2006) leaning against a vehicle out front of 2211 N. Locust St. While checking his wanted status, Harris observed the officers, at which point he immediately turned and began to flee into the residence, while grabbing his waistband.
Detectives immediately pursued Harris. While established a perimeter around the residence, Harris then exited the front door and was taken into custody without incident. While on scene, Detectives obtained consent to search during which time they located and recovered a Taurus G2C 9mm (S/N: ADB004944) handgun, a Sig Sauer P320 9mm (S/N: M18A001395) handgun, 1.98 grams of heroin and a total of 83 rounds of ammunition.
While on scene, the owner of the residence confirmed Harris, Damir Williams (01/26/2007) and Jihad Brown, all stay in the basement of the residence. This is where the Taurus and heroin were recovered. Williams was on scene, at the time of the investigation; charges are pending further investigation.
Harris and the evidence were transported to Central.
not in gunstat meeting reports

During the month of August 2023, Det. Deveraux and Cuadrado initiated an investigation into drug sales in the 1200
block of W. 3rd Street, by Antwine Witcher BM 08/28/1986. Through the course of the investigation, it was determined that several
subjects, including Antwine Witcher and Tyrone Pryor BM 10/24/1996 were engaged in drug sales from the aforementioned block
and out of 1202 W. 3rd St., Wilmington, DE. Additionally, information was obtained that these subjects possessed multiple firearms.
Through the course of this investigation, a search warrant was authored and obtained for the defendants and the residence.
On August 29, 2023 at 2352 hours, Wilcom received a ShotSpotter notification for six rounds in the 200 block of North Harrison
Street. Preliminary information revealed the casings recovered were .32 Auto. These were located in the 1200 block of W. 3rd Street.
WPD case # 30-23-64622.
On August 24, 2023, at 1508 hours, DOCV detectives conducted a pedestrian stop on Tyrone Pryor BM 10/24/1996 (who gave a
false name of Darrell Young) in the area of W. 3rd & Jefferson St. Pryor advised that he lived at 1202 W. 3rd St. While in turnkey,
Pryor provided his real name and was found to have three active capiases. During a strip search, Pryor was found to be in possession
of 8 ziploc baggies containing (.056 grams) of Heroin/Fentanyl stamped “Cold Pack” and approximately (.01 grams) of crack cocaine.
At approximately 1551 hours, members of the Wilmington Police Department CMTT, DOCV, CGIC, CID, K9, and UAV, executed
the search warrant at 1202 W 3rd Street, Wilmington without incident. Located in the residence and taken into custody were Michelle
Rogers BF 08/07/83, Darren Staats BM 06/16/85 and Antwine Witcher BM 08/28/86. Jawan Hamilton BM 02/20/89 was also taken
into custody outside of the residence for failing to obey orders to get back.
During a search of the residence officers located a loaded silver/brown in color Davis Industries, .32 caliber semi-automatic handgun
(#P179493) located under the middle couch cushion in the living room.
Michelle Rogers told detectives she was the operator of the maroon 2021 Dodge Charger (DE 491124) and provided consent for
officers to search the vehicle. Michelle advised officers that she had a loaded black .380 handgun in the backpack in the rear of the
vehicle. During a consent search, officers located a loaded black S&W M&P bodyguard, .380 caliber semi-automatic handgun
(#KHX4080) which was legally owned by Michelle Rogers. Roger further advised officers that Tyrone Pryor did possess the handgun
earlier in the day.
During a search of the residence, officers located and seized the following items:
• Paperwork for Antwine Witcher along with Witcher’s wallet and ID located in the first floor back bedroom
• A box containing numerous empty blue glassine baggies in the kitchen closet
• (11) rounds of .32 ammunition in the kitchen closet
• loose round of .32 auto ammunition on the floor in the upstairs front bedroom
• loose round of 9mm ammunition on the floor in the upstairs middle bedroom
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Thursday December 29th 2206 hours, D Platoon Officers were in the 1600 block of Jessup St when they observed the defendant (Rashad Walker BM 05/12/93) displaying characteristics of an armed gunman. Officers attempted to make contact with same, during which time WALKER fled on foot towards the 16th Street Bridge, discarding a handgun into the Brandywine Creek before being taken into custody.  Walker is a convicted felon with criminal history involving firearms, drug dealing and shooting. He is also a Level 3 probationer. Operation Safe Streets was contacted and advised that he is currently on Level 3 probation for a firearm offense and a Non Compliance with Bond charge, which was pled down from an Assault 1st/Shooting that occurred on 8/6/2020 in the area of 23/Carter (30-20-65405).  Street Smart bulletins also have WALKER identified on the “E 17th St & Vandever Ave” affiliates.
Sgt Tiberi was able to facilitate contact with DSP’s Dive team for their assistance in attempting to retrieve the firearm from the water. As a result of the coordination and efforts involving DSP, the Defendant’s loaded Black and Gray in color SCCY, CPX9, 9mm Semi-automatic handgun (Serial # 496382) was recovered from the Brandywine River.  Data confirmed that the gun was stolen out of WPD Jurisdiction (30-22-56499).  The firearm was turned over to FSU for processing.  WALKER was ultimately charged with Possession of a Firearm/Ammo Prohibited, Carrying Concealed Firearm, Hindering Prosecution, and Resisting Arrest.  He is currently being held at Howard Young Correctional on $23,000 cash bail, and an administrative warrant regarding his violations of probation.

On September 10th, at approximately 0830 hours, members of Safe Streets responded to 214 N Broom St, Apt C,
in order to serve a PFA to Edward James (03/04/1969) who is on level 1 probation for DUI. Additionally, Det. Joe Miller provided
Safe Streets with a copy of a Family Court “Writ of Injunction/Sequestration” granting officers permission to search the residence
for a shotgun that was allegedly inside his bedroom.
Members of Safe Streets knocked on the door, identified themselves and announced their reason for being at the residence. Officers
then heard commotion coming from inside the apartment. Seconds later, officers holding the exterior, rear containment observed
Rahman Moody (05/15/2006) exit a window to the rooftop and throw a bag to the rear yards.
Moody then went back inside the apartment and opened the door at which time he was detained without incident. Officers
recovered the bag which contained a Taurus .357 Magnum Revolver (SN #5229883), ammunition, .105 grams of heroin, and .8
grams of cocaine. James was not at the residence at the time of this investigation, and Moody advised that he had just moved to
South Carolina within the past week – relationship to the two is unknown.

On Friday October 28, 2023. At approximately 2112 hours, officers were dispatched to 1712 Lancaster Avenue for a
report of an assault with a weapon. Responding Officers made contact with the Victim, Davonte Gibbs who advised that he was
walking in the area of Tilton Park located in the 700 block of N. Broom Street, when he was approached by Mehki Johnson BM
10/07/2005, the defendant. Gibbs advised that he knows Johnson because he used to date Johnson’s cousin. During the encounter,
Johnson brandished a firearm and threatened to kill Gibbs. After pointing the gun at Gibbs, Johnson struck him over the head with the
firearm, causing a laceration to Gibbs’ head. Following the assault, Gibbs responded back to his above listed residence and called the
police to report the incident. Officer Stewart conducted an area search for Johnson, locating him in Tilton Park. Upon observing
Officer Stewart, Johnson began walking away, while displaying characteristics of an armed person. As Officer Stewart approached
Johnson, he immediately fled on foot. Officer Stewart pursued Johnson and was able to place him into custody in the 1300 block of
W. 7th Street without further incident. During a retrace of Johnson’s direction of travel, Officer Stewart located Springfield 9mm
semiautomatic handgun (s/n: LW180155). The firearm was loaded with 1 round in the chamber and 6 rounds in the magazine. An
NCIC inquiry of the firearm determined that the gun was reported stolen to WPD (30-23-030231). Johnson was transported to Central,
where he was interviewed under Miranda. During the interview, Johnson admitted to possessing the firearm and striking Gibbs in the
head with the gun. Johnson was charged with CCDW, PFDCF, receiving a stolen firearm, assault 2nd, agg menacing, and resisting.

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On Monday, June 23, 2025, at approximately 0945 hours, CGIC investigators were contacted by Probation Officer Crist to assist at 119 Buck Lane, in reference to an admin search of the residence. It should be known that the subject, Salahadin Shahid (01/06/2006), resides at the address and is currently on level two interstate probation from Chester, Pennsylvania for a firearm charge. Officer Crist advised that Delaware Probation had an approved administrative search due to Shahid displaying firearms on a recent prison call that was monitored which appeared to take place within his listed residence.
On June 23rd, 2025, at approximately 0945 hours, during an approved administrative search; Probation Officer Crist advised they located a tan in color 9mm handgun magazine loaded with ammunition under the covers of Shahid's bedroom. Furthermore, Probation Officers located a "jig" that contained the lower receiver to an un-finished rifle and several multi-caliber rounds of ammunition from handgun ammunition to rifle ammunition. It should be known that Probation Officers also located and recovered six (6) bags of heroin, approximately 0.18 grams, in a plastic dresser next to Shahid's bed. Further investigation led to the recovery of:” 1. Black in color "Mini Draco" Ak-47 style rifle equipped with a fore-grip and front optic sight, loaded with ammunition in the magazine and in the chamber. 2. Black and grey in color assault rifle multi-caliber style with a tampered serial number. 3. Black in color upper for a rifle. 4. Black in color duffle bag containing the following: Black in color magazine containing six (6) live 10mm rounds of ammunition, two (2) empty thirty (30) round rifle magazines, one (1) empty thirty (3) round rifle magazine in the packaging, one (1) thirty (30) round rifle magazine containing twenty-nine (29) .223 rounds of ammunition, sixteen (16) .45 caliber rounds of ammunition, one (1) loose round of .223 ammunition, a slide to a black in color Taurus PT740 and spring Serial #SGT34225, empty box of .223 ammunition, Armors wrench tool, Fifty (50) round drum magazine containing sixteen (16) 7.62 rounds, a green in color upper to a rifle and other misc firearm parts and accessories. A further search of the residence, the following items were located and recovered in the closet under the attic door, in close proximity to Shahid's bedroom: 1. Black in color Privately Made Firearm "PMF" with a camo grip sleeve, loaded with seventeen (17) 9mm rounds in the magazine and one (1) in the chamber, no serial number. It should be noted that the camo grip sleeve was strikingly similar to the camo grip sleeve, which was observed on the aforementioned monitored video prison call.2. Another black in color lower receiver to a rifle. Det. Lerro and Linkhorst conducted a post Miranda interview with Shahid who admitted to being the possessor/owner of all the firearms and firearm parts and ammunition located in the home.

On Monday April 15 at approximately 1845 hours, M/Cpl. Wiggins and Officer Thompson observed a vehicle
being operated without a tint waiver in the 500 block of E. 35th Street. Officers conducted a traffic stop and spoke with operator,
Mohammed Rahim WM 01/11/2001. Officers conducted a DELJIS check on the operator and found same to have two active capias’
for Driving While Suspended. The operator was removed from the vehicle and when asked if he has any weapons, he advised that he
had a firearm in his backpack. Officers located the backpack and recovered a black in color Glock 19 serial # BZTC907 firearm with
a 30 round extended magazine which contained 1 live round. In addition to the firearm, Officers located approximately 111 grams of
marijuana. The defendant was charged with CCDW and possession of Marijuana with a Firearm.

dealer_name: Target Master (license name Tommy Gun Inc)
case_summary: On Friday, July 18, 2025, at approximately 0008 hours, WPD officers were on a proactive patrol in the area of West 4th and Delamore Place, when they observed a black in color Jeep Compass (DE temp XF506882) with illegal window tint. Officers then made a vehicle stop and made contact with the driver, Andre Norwood (05/24/1987). The front passenger was identified as Malikye Boyer (09/15/2001), and the rear passenger was identified as Davonte Talbert (04/13/2008). A DELJIS inquiry revealed the driver, Andre Norwood, to have a suspended license, where officers then asked him to step out of the vehicle. Due to the suspended license, officers decided to tow the vehicle, and asked the other occupants to exit the vehicle. Upon doing so, Boyer was observed to have a Glock 43X 9mm (SN#BUTW391) in his front waistband. The firearm was later confirmed to be stolen out of NCCPD. A search of the vehicle revealed a Ruger Security .380 (SN#38707248) to be found underneath the front passenger seat, being in close proximity to both Boyer and Talbert. Officers also located a total of 183 grams of Marijuana, a digital scale, and USC in the vehicle. The individuals were brought back to Central, where DNA was taken, and charged accordingly.

On Saturday June 25th 1407 hours, D Platoon Officers responded to the 1300 block of W 3rd St for a person with a
gun complaint. The complainant stated that he was involved in a verbal argument with Robert Foster and further stated that he
observed Foster remove a firearm out of a black shopping bag and place it in a green camping bag. Officers observed Robert Foster
BM 10/30/91, who matched the suspect description, and stopped same. Foster admitted he had a firearm in his bag which belonged to
his sister. A black in color Sig Sauer P320 9mm handgun with a red dot sight was located inside the backpack. The firearm was loaded
with 14 rounds and 1 in the chamber.

On Wednesday April 17, 2024, at approximately 2200 hours, members of Safe Streets where on proactive patrol when they observed a red in color Jeep Grand Cherokee with an expired registration in the 100 block of W. 21st St.  A vehicle stop was conducted and officers made contact with the sole occupant, Avery Quartlebaum BM 10/31/2005.  During a consent search of the vehicle, officers located a Taurus 9mm handgun (#ACE895193), loaded with five rounds of ammunition under the front passenger seat. The firearm was reported stolen out of New Castle County Police jurisdiction.  Avery was taken into custody without incident. Officers were granted consent to search Avery’s residence at 108 W. 21st St where they located a Glock 17 9mm handgun (#AGFY457) as well as numerous rounds of 9mm ammunition in the basement. Avery was transported to Central where he admitted to owning the Taurus that was located in the vehicle.  He further stated that he purchased the gun for $150 on 04/11/24, but he claimed the Glock found in the basement did not belong to him.  DNA was collected from Avery and test fire forms were completed for both firearms.  Avery was charged accordingly and released after posting a $6,100 unsecured bail.

On Wednesday January 3, 2024, at 0841 hours, C Platoon officers responded to 1401 Maryland Avenue, Apartment
D12, regarding a shooting. Upon arrival, officers located the victim suffering from a GSW to his left palm. The victim, Jake Slocomb,
a Constable with the Delaware Capital Police, advised officers he was at the residence to evict Raymundo Guzman WMH
03/15/1986. Upon arrival, Slocomb met with the property manager who advised him that the suspect was threatening to kill himself.
When Slocomb made contact with the suspect, he asked the suspect if he had any weapons on his person to which the suspect replied
in the affirmative. Slocomb removed a Sterling .22 caliber handgun from the suspects left pocket. The handgun was found to be in
poor condition with several live rounds and a casing “stuck in the barrel”. As Slocomb attempted to manipulate the firearm in order to
make it safe, same discharged into his hand. The victim was transported to CER for treatment. The suspect was taken into custody. He
was not a person prohibited; however, after consultation with the Department of Justice, the decision was made to charge the
defendant with CCDW since he was outside his residence with the firearm concealed on his person. The firearm was 29N and tagged
for additional testing

On Thursday June 13, 2024, at approximately 0905 hours, the Wilmington Police Communications Unit received a
911 call for shots fired at 2834 Rosemont Avenue. The caller said a projectile came through their wall and nearly struck a juvenile.
Units responded to 2834 Rosemont and determined that a projectile came through a second-floor wall from the adjoining house
(2832). Officers spoke with the victim, who said she was in her room when the projectile came through the wall, went through her
television, and then lodged into her bed. Her arm sustained an abrasion from fragments of the television/bed.
Officers established a perimeter around 2832 Rosemont Avenue and then used the loudspeaker to order the occupants to exit. Stephan
Deshields BM 08/22/2006 exited without incident and was taken into custody by officers. Officers debriefed Mr. Deshields and
determined he was the sole occupant. With the assistance of CID, officers applied for a search warrant for 2832 Rosemont Avenue,
which was granted. Officers searched the house and located three firearms, ammunition (9mm, .22 cal, 12 gauge), and numerous
credit cards with various names. Officers recovered the following guns:
• Pink Glock 9mm Model 19 (Serial # AGKA918), Extended Magazine, No NCIC Record. A casing was lodged in the
ejection port as a result of a double-feed
• Black Glock 9mm Model 19 (Serial # MP2843DC), Standard Magazine, No NCIC Record
• Brown Canik 9mm TP9SF (Serial # T6472-21), Extended Magazine, No NCIC Record
The investigation is ongoing as Officers Mann/Diaz are collecting statements, DNA, and gunshot residue. However, preliminary
information revealed that Mr. Deshields discharged a firearm in the second-floor bedroom of 2832 Rosemont Avenue. The projectile
went through the wall and entered the second-floor bedroom of 2834 Rosemont Avenue.

On Monday October 02, 2023, Det. Rosaio observed Julius Ventura BM 05/09/2005 and Jayden Smith walking in
the 700 block of Catawba Street during which time Julius Ventura removed a firearm that was concealed in his waistband. Both
subjects then entered the Rutledge apartment building located at 312 W. 8th Street before members of the Vice Unit could conduct a
stop on them. Members of the Vice Unit with the assistance of Patrol, CID, and the Gun Unit established a perimeter of the apartment
building exterior and simultaneously cleared the interior. Contact was made with the property management company who were able to
determine both subjects entered apartment #16. Shortly after, Julius Ventura and Jayden Smith exited apartment 16 and were detained
without incident. Ventura was immediately interviewed and advised that his grandmother and a young female were still in the
apartment. Both Ventura and Smith were transported to Central.
Investigators made numerous, unsuccessful attempts by various means to contact the grandmother. Members of the Hostage
Negotiation Team that were present were unsuccessful in making contact with the grandmother. Det. Rosaio authored and obtained a
search warrant for the aforementioned location. Upon executing the warrant contact was made with the grandmother and a young
female who denied hearing officers at her door. Located inside the residence: black in color Ruger Security 9mm semi-automatic
handgun (#385-42148) and a black in color Ruger 5.7 x 28 semi-automatic handgun with a partially obliterated serial number (#642-
19207), 25.9 grams of marijuana and drug paraphernalia.
Julius Ventura admitted to owning and possessing the Ruger Security 9mm semi-automatic handgun but not the Ruger 5.7x28 caliber
semi-automatic handgun which he claims belongs to his older brother.
The firearms as well as the Test Fire Form were submitted to FSU for processing. DNA was obtained from both Ventura and Smith

On December 2, 2025, at approximately 2128 hours, Officer Crumlish was in the area of 700 W. 8th St, when he conducted a motor vehicle stop, in reference to a window tint violation. Contact was made with the driver, Nahsir Doss (06/21/1999), who admitted to having a weapon in the vehicle. Following a search of the vehicle, Officer Crumlish located a loaded Ruger RXM 9mm
(SN#094-53744) handgun concealed between the driver’s seat and the center console. Additionally, a Ruger gun box containing 36 rounds of 9mm ammunition was located in the trunk. Doss was taken back to Central and charged accordingly.

On Wednesday May 3rd 1310 hours, D Platoon officers were in the 700 block of W. 5th St on a preventative patrol when (Cpl. Trent Martin) observed Kenai Truitt BM 01/26/1997 who he knew to be a person of interest by the Criminal Investigations Division. A pedestrian stop was conducted and Truitt was taken into custody without incident. Search incident to arrest revealed a black in color loaded Stoeger STR-9 9mm handgun in his waistband area. It should be noted Truitt is a known OMB gang member and a person prohibited due to a robbery conviction in 2015

On Saturday May 27th 0118 hours, Officers Ricardo Flores and Hakeem Brown were working an extra duty job at
110 South West Street (Dockland’s). At approximately 0118, the officers observed Keon Brown BM 05/19/88 and Nakia Jones BF 07/16/87 walking together after exiting the establishment. Mr. Brown dropped a firearm as he walked. Ms. Jones picked it up and attempted to conceal it (later admitting the gun was hers). The officers initiated an investigation into their actions and discovered neither had a concealed carry permit. Additionally, they determined that Mr. Brown was a person prohibited from possessing a
firearm. During the arrest, Ms. Jones spat on Officer Flores (saliva landed on his uniform) and threatened to kill the
investigating/assisting officers. The officers recovered a black 9mm Beretta APX (Serial #: A139820X) and two magazines (a total of nineteen 9mm rounds). An NCIC search revealed that the firearm had not been reported stolen.

On May 8, 2025, at approximately 2045 hours, officers were on a homicide scene with DAG Abessinio and DAG
Kenney, as FSU detectives were concluding their processing. At this time, a female, later identified as Nakia Jones (07/16/1987)
approached the area and seemed heavily intoxicated. As she approached, Jones pushed a trashcan towards Sgt. Rodrigues and
attempted to push Sgt. Fox. Officers directed Jones towards her residence of 2118 N. Church St, where they then responded back to the
original scene. Jones continued to talk at officers and make threats, while they did not engage.
Jones then proceeds to pull a firearm out from her person and place it on the porch bannister. She then continues to threaten officers, while reaching for her waistband revealing a second firearm. Officer take cover while continuing to issue verbal commands to Jones who was holding and waving the firearm towards officers and deputies. During this time, Jones’ children opened the porch door behind, watching the incident unfold. Jones was placed into custody without further incident. The firearms were seized and recovered to be #1 Smith and Wesson M&P 9 Shield Plus 9mm (S/N: JJD4358) loaded handgun and #2 Smith and Wesson M&P 9 Shield EZ 9mm (S/N: NHD8814) loaded handgun. Inside the residence, officers located multiple loaded magazines and loose ammunition throughout the living room. The three young juveniles who were inside the residence, were transported to their grandmother’s care.

On October 23, 2024, at approximately 1354 hours, CGIC investigators were driving westbound through the 400blk
of E 3rd Street, when they observed an individual with what appeared to be a firearm in their right front jacket pocket. Investigators
exited their police vehicle to make contact, which at this point, the subject began to flee. After a brief foot pursuit, the subject,
identified as Richard Flippin (DOB 10/18/2001) was placed into custody without further incident. A black Desert Eagle Magnum
9mm (S/N #41314451) with 12 rounds in the magazine was recovered from his right front jacket pocket. Flippin’s was also in
possession of six (6) bags of suspected heroin.

On Friday July 22nd 0624 hours, Detective Coffiey was assisting Det. Cannon and the USMS in a warrant attempt at
1320 Clifford Brown Walk Apt. 401 for Arkye Matthews BM 04/16/04 in relation to the shooting of Jarrod Reams (27th & NE Blvd –
06/21/22). Upon arrival, officers observed a subject (later identified as Khalil Demonia) attempting to discard a firearm out of the 4th
floor window at which time USMS breached the door. Located inside the apartment was Arkye Matthews BM 04/16/04, Khalil
Demonia BM 05/03/99 and Devaughn Matthews BM 10/14/00. Marijuana was observed in plain view and Khalil Demonia advised
that he attempted to throw a digital scale out of the window. Demonia then provided verbal and written consent to search the residence
which resulted in the recovery of (25.9 grams) of marijuana, a digital scale, and a Sig Sauer 9mm handgun loaded with 12 rounds in
the magazine and none in the chamber. The firearm was located inside a trash bag in the kitchen. DNA was obtained from all subjects.
Devaughn Matthews was released with no charges (pending DNA).
Arkye Matthews was processed on Conspiracy 2nd (x2)
Khalil Demonia was processed on the firearm and T16 offenses
not in gunstat meeting reports

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On May 12, 2025, at approximately 0251 hours, officers responded to 6 Servan Ct, in reference to a ShotSpotter alert for one round. Upon arrival, officers observed a white Chevrolet Silverado (DE C92378) parked in front of 4 Servan Ct. It should be noted that WILCOM had two prior complaints hours earlier, for aggravated menacing incidents involving a white Chevrolet Silverado. 
Based on the vehicle description and the ShotSpotter notification, Officer Hutt approached the vehicle. The driver was identified as Carlos Charriez (12/15/1991). Charriez was asked to step out of the vehicle and was pat down for officer safety. While doing so, officers observed a live round of ammunition on the floorboard, in plain view. A probable cause search was then conducted, and at this time, a Glock 19C Gen 5 9mm (SN#CBUL303) handgun was located underneath the driver’s seat. Charriez was then taken into custody and transported to Central. 
On May 20, 2025, at approximately 1117 hours, Officers J. Miller and Rogers responded to the area to do a recanvas of the original scene. In the area, officers located one (1) 9mm casings. FSU responded to collect the evidence and do further processing.

On April 2nd, 2025, at 2342, Officers Marshall and Lopez were in the area of 26th and Thatcher Streets when they
observed a blue Dodge Journey (DE PC418538) fail to stop at the stop sign. At this time, officers conducted a motor vehicle stop in the
3500 block of Northeast Boulevard. The passenger, later identified as Nhasir Lewis (03/18/2003) began acting nervous and displaying
characteristics of an armed person. The occupants were asked to exit the vehicle, which is when Lewis was learned to be in possession
of a black Taurus G2C 9mm (S/N: TMS74150). Lewis was taken into custody and transported. Driver, Deandre Short, (05-03-2002)
was issued an E-Ticket for failure to stop and released.
not in gunstat meeting reports

On July 23, 2024 officers received a call from Wilcom regarding a subject in a vehicle who was in possession of a firearm and narcotics in the area. The officers converged on the area and located the defendant, Donte Parker 08/11/1982, loading items into his vehicle in the 300 block of N. Harrison Street.  Both Parker and the vehicle matched the description provided by the caller to Wilcom.  The officers engaged Parker in conversation and he admitted that a firearm was inside his vehicle. He was placed into custody and transported to central.  His vehicle as towed pending a search warrant. A search warrant was applied for and granted to search the vehicle.  Officers recovered (11) eleven grams of crack cocaine, numerous packaging materials, and a Taurus .38 special revolver (S/N #KD16453) and (5) five rounds of ammunition.
not in gunstat meeting reports
not in gunstat meeting reports

On July 1st, 2024 at approximately 0454 hours, C Platoon responded to the 400 block of N. Franklin
St in reference to a shot spotter notification for 6 rounds. No casings recovered. Over the following weeks, CGIC initiated an
investigation into the incident and the TRU unit was able to locate and recover video surveillance of the incident. CGIC
detectives recogonized the suspects and vehicle and as a result, they applied for and were granted search warrants for the
suspect’s residence 308 S Union St and vehicle. On July 16th, 2024 CGIC along with members of Safe Streets established
surveillance on 308 S Union St along with the black in color Dodge Ram. During this time, Eduardo Gomez WMH
02/10/1991 was observed exiting the residence multiple times placing bags into a black in color Ford F150. Detectives
attempted to make contact with Eduardo and took him into custody after a brief struggle. Once Eduardo was in custody,
Detectives made contact with Ricarda Sandoval WFH 04/03/1998 and three children inside of the residence. During a search
of the residence Detectives located and recovered the following:
 67.7 grams of Meth
 5.8 grams of Crack Cocaine
 10.2 grams of Marijuana
 Packaging Material
Eduardo, Ricarda, the evidence and both vehicles were transported to the Wilmington Police Department where detectives
executed search warrants on the vehicles. The following items were recovered from same:
 Black in color American Tactical Mil Sport AR-15 (S/N MSA033411), 13 rounds of .223 ammunition.
 185.4 grams of Meth
 14.4 grams of Cocaine
 20 rounds of 9mm ammunition
 37 Shotgun Shells, 40 rounds of 7.62 X 39, 1 Spent .223 casing
Ricarda was interviewed regarding these incidents and confirmed her involvement regarding the shots fired in the 400 block of
Franklin St as well as confirmed Eduardo was the one who fired. Immigration and Customs was contacted and advised
regarding Eduardo.

On 8/3/2022 @ approximately 1134 hours, SCU Officers were in the area of the 700 block of Tatnall Street when officers observed the defendant identified as (Brown, Rahmere BM 08/25/2007) possessing characteristics of an armed gunmen. Upon seeing SCU officers, the defendant and two other subjects began walking north on Tatnall. SCU Officers approached the subjects in the 800 block
of Tatnall Street at which time the defendant fled into the rear stocking area of the (Tatnall Deli & Market) 310 west 8th Street. The defendant secured himself inside the store bathroom and came out after several verbal commands and was taken into custody without incident. During the search of the store, Officers located a loaded “Springfield” 9mm Luger Model Hellcat SN# BA172864 containing (13) rounds in the gun and (1) in the magazine.
Firearm was checked locally and NCIC and found to be Stolen on 8/1/22 out of NCCPD 32-22-58419

On Monday June 20th 1707 hours, A Platoon officers (Kline / S. Connor) responded to 736 Townsend Place in
reference to an aggravated menacing complaint. Upon arrival, officers spoke with the victim who advised that there is an ongoing feud
between her and the defendant, Nicole Charles, over an ex-boyfriend. She advised that she was sitting in the passenger seat of a
friend’s vehicle in front of her residence when Charles pulled up and the two began arguing. Charles produced a pink in color handgun
from inside her vehicle and discharged one round in the direction of the victim before fleeing the area. While officers were at the
incident location, the defendant returned and was seen open carrying a pink in color SCCY CPX-2 on her right hip. The defendant was
stopped by officers and admitted to firing a warning shot at the ground when the victim was approaching her in an aggressive manner.
Charles was placed into custody without incident and transported to central for processing

On Sunday October 1st, at approximately 0107 hours this unit 11-David (Ludlam) responded to 1014 N. Lombard Street in reference to a shots fired complaint. Upon arrival, assisting units investigated and found that a fight had broken out that involved the residents of 1014 Lombard Street and a group of females. During the altercation Nicole Hinson BF 04/06/1976 exited the residence of 1014 N. Lombard Street and fired two (2) rounds into the air causing the group to flee. A witness advised that he observed Nicole exit her residence and fire two rounds into the air and return inside of the residence. For police safety, all occupants inside the residence were identified. During this time, Officer Martin made contact with Alexander Letitia BF 01/09/2002 who advised that she was coming out of the second floor bedroom with an unloaded firearm. Alexander handed over a Stoeger STR-9SC 9mm handgun which was fully loaded. Thru investigation it was discovered that a different firearm was used during the shots fired incident. Officer Ludlam attempted to get a search warrant consent form from Nicole, but she refused. Nicole was taken into custody without incident and transported to central for processing. A night time search warrant for the residence was approved by Judge Michelle Michini. Officer Meese and Officer Hutt conducted the search of the residence and recovered the correct firearm a Smith and Wesson MP 9MM (Serial Number HLA0475) with one (1) round 9mm in the chamber and seven (7) rounds in the magazine which was located in the master bedroom.

On Wednesday September 20th 2030 hours, officers responded to a ShotSpotter alert at 408 E. 8th Street for two (2) rounds. An anonymous caller described the suspects as two black males, dressed in all black, on a motorized scooter. While responding into the area, 16-Adam (Rumford/Simpler) observed a black male dressed in all black on a motorized scooter leaving the area, southbound on N. Lombard Street. 16-Adam was able to catch up to and approach the subject, later identified as Kajuan Warren BM 08/05/1994, in the 400 block of Robinson Street, at which time he immediately fled on foot and attempted to enter a home in the block. After a very brief foot pursuit, the defendant was placed into custody without incident. The defendant was in possession of a black in color, 9mm Glock 34 Gen 5 handgun loaded with13 rounds in the 17 round magazine and one in the chamber (Serial #BUGC969, not stolen) which was concealed on his person. The firearm was equipped with a flashlight and red laser. The defendant also possessed 127 bags of heroin (stamped Black Ace and Last Sigh). A Street Smart search for the defendant only returned that the same is on the East Side bulletin. It should be known that officers canvassed the original ShotSpotter location for a scene, witnesses or video surveillance, but met with negative results.

On Saturday January 21st 1122 hours, SCU Investigators received information from a past proven reliable informant
that a subject wearing all black and grey clothing was in possession of a firearm in the area of W 7th & Washington. SCU Investigators
responded to City Watch and obtained a visual through the 6th & Jefferson St camera. While reviewing the camera, Investigators
located a subject matching the description standing on the steps of the (Family Deli & Grocery) corner store. The subject was
observed then walking south on Washington Street and entering the front passenger seat of a vehicle parked nearby. Investigators
made contact with the vehicle and observed the defendant, Omar Rodriquez BM (04/21/2000) make a furtive movement with his
hands. The defendant was removed from the vehicle at which time Investigators observed marijuana inside the defendant’s hand.
Incident to arrest, the defendant was searched and found to be in possession of a loaded silver/brown Taurus PT 9mm (#T1193603)
which was located inside the defendant’s front waistband.

On Tuesday June 14th 1842 hours, SCU officers were in the 2400 block of N. Tatnall St when they observed Michael Braxton BM 06/25/02 operating a bicycle on the eastern side of the sidewalk of N. Tatnall St. It should be known that you cannot operate a bicycle on a sidewalk and must obey all traffic laws while operating same. Officers drove their police vehicle past Braxton, at which time Braxton attempted to quickly flee south of N. Tatnall to avoid police contact. Officers were able to stop Braxton after a brief struggle and placed same into custody. Located inside the defendant’s waistband was a loaded S&W M&P .40 caliber firearm. Braxton was also in possession of (4.4 grams) of Crack Cocaine. 

Person(s) Contacted: Darmond Green BM 03/29/06 & Vincent Hodge BM 04/18/05

During the month of October, members of Safe Streets began a firearm investigation involving Naseer Bullock
(02/01/2007). On October 15, 2025, Safe Streets established surveillance on Bullock’s listed address of 30 W. 36th St. At approximately
1945 hours, Bullock arrived at the residence, driving a VW Passat (NJ: F73SLM). Bullock was detained and found to be in possession of
marijuana, which was in the vehicle. Officers search the residence, where they recovered a FN 503 9mm (SN#CV022337) handgun, a
Glock 17 9mm (SN#CDGM422) handgun in Bullock’s bedroom, along with additional marijuana and drug packaging material. While on
scene, Angel Morrow (02/06/2008) approached officers, advising the FN firearm belong to him. He was able to describe distinct features
on the weapon, therefore, he was taken into custody without incident. Both Bullock and Morrow were charged accordingly.

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On June 21, 2025, CGIC detectives were contact by Cpl Dan Shea regarding Ni’jeir Oliver (07/25/2003). Cpl Shea
advised A Platoon handled an aggravated menacing which occurred in the area of 1700 Lancaster Ave (30-25-044942), in which they
were able to identify Oliver as a suspect and sign an arrest warrant for same. Over the following days, CGIC conducted an investigation, with the assistance of Probation, and were able to confirm 230 Delamore
Place as Oliver’s residence. Detectives applied for and were granted a search warrant.
On June 24, 2025advised A Platoon handled an aggravated menacing which occurred in the area of 1700 Lancaster Ave (30-25-044942), in which they were able to identify Oliver as a suspect and sign an arrest warrant for same.
Over the following days, CGIC conducted an investigation, with the assistance of Probation, and were able to confirm 230 Delamore Place as Oliver’s residence. Detectives applied for and were granted a search warrant.
On June 24, 2025, Detectives established surveillance on the residence at which point Oliver was observed exiting the residence and entering a blue in color Honda. A vehicle stop was conducted in the area of 5th and N. Scott St, where Oliver was taken into custody. Once
in custody, Detective4s executed the search warrant at 230 Delamore Place. During a search of the residence a black and silver Sarsilmaz SAR9C 9mm (S/N: T1102-25CG00290) handgun was located and recovered.

On November 20, 2024, CGIC detectives established surveillance in the area of W. 31st St and N. Jefferson St in
reference to Nykii Brown (11/30/2000) in reference to a Aggravated Menacing incident (30-24-086727) which occurred on
November 13th being investigated by Cpl Mann. During Cpl Mann’s investigation, he was able to positively ID Nykii as his suspect
and obtained an arrest warrant for same.
At approximately 1353 hours, Brown was observed exiting 320 W. 31st St and walking southbound in the 3000 block of N.
Jefferson St. CGIC detectives made contact with Nykii and were able to take him into custody without incident. Nykii was found
to be in possession of a black in color Taurus G3C 9mm (S/N #AED274965) firearm loaded with 13 total rounds of ammunition.
Once in custody, Cpl Mann applied for and was granted a search warrant for 320 W. 31st St in reference to his investigation.
During a search of the residence, Cpl Mann recovered 53 rounds of 9mm ammunition, 2 Taurus magazines, 2 holsters, and
clothing

On December 15, 2023, at approximately 2045 hours, members of Safe Streets observed blue in color Ford Fusion (DE 164256) fail to stop for the stop sign located at 9th and Church Streets.  A vehicle stop was conducted in the 1200 block of Northeast Blvd. where officers made contact with the driver, Nyzear Burton, and his passenger, Cleve Wright Jr.
	Burton does not possess a valid driver’s license and was found to have a WPD hard warrant for criminal mischief.  He was subsequently removed from the vehicle, and officers located the above listed firearm concealed in the glove box.  Both Burton and Wright were transported to Central.  Burton admitted that the firearm belonged to him, but he did not possess a concealed carry permit.  Wright consented to have his DNA collected prior to being released from Central.  Burton also consented to have his DNA collected.  The firearm was not reported stolen, and Burton was charged accordingly.  Burton is currently being held at HRYCI after failing to post his $8,000 cash bail.
	Nyzear Burton is the brother of Zyair Burton (OMB) who was the victim of a homicide on 9/25/23.  According to the 9/26/23 intelligence bulletin, Nyzear Burton is a member of the “CBG Southbridge Crew”.  Cleve Wright Jr. is also an associate of “CBG”.

defendant_name: Elija Kamara, Davonte Talbert, Jayden Robinson
case_summary:
Over the past two weeks, CGIC conducted an investigation in collaboration with Mantua Township Police
Department, Gloucester County Prosecutors Office, Salem County Prosecutors Office and USMS regarding the vehicle theft of a
USMS vehicle containing two (2) rifles and a handgun which occurred in Mantua New Jersey.
During the course of the investigation, the stolen USMS vehicle was recovered in NCCPD jurisdiction along with an additional
stolen vehicle believed to be involved which was recovered the area of E 17th and N. Locust St. Throughout the investigation, Elija
Kamara (11/09/05) was developed as a suspect along with Davonte Talbert (04/13/08), and Jayden Robinson (11/25/04).
As a result of the investigation, detectives applied for and were granted search warrants for the following residences: 2304 Lamotte
St. Wilmington DE, 820 Vandever Ave. Wilmington DE, 8 Kent Pl. Newark DE, and 10555 Price Dr. Milford DE.
On January 30th, 2025 members of CGIC executed the search warrants at 820 Vandever and 2304 Lamotte St with the assistance of
CMTT, Safe Streets, DOCV, K9, FBI and NCCPD SWAT while members of CGIC along with DSP Sort, Probation, USMS, and the
ATF executing the search warrant at 8 Kent Place. During this time, Davonte Talbert was taken into custody at 2304 Lamotte St.
As a result of the search warrants, detectives located and recovered a black in color Glock 27 handgun loaded with 13 rounds of 40
caliber ammunition from 2304 Lamotte St and a black in color PMF 40 caliber handgun loaded with 14 rounds of 40 caliber
ammunition from 8 Kent Place. The Glock 27 was confirmed to be one of the firearm stolen from USMS vehicle.
While executing the search warrants, USMS executed a search warrant in Brookhaven PA where the located and apprehended Elija.
During a search of the residence, a Sig Sauer .556 rifle and a PMF 9mm handgun were located and recovered. The Sig Sauer rifle
was confirmed to be one of the rifles stolen from the USMS vehicle.
Davonte and the evidence were transported to the Wilmington Police Department.
While at central, detectives were advised of Jayden’s location at which point a search warrant was authored and granted. Members
of DSP SORT and the USMS executed the warrant and took Jayden into custody without incident. During a search of the residence,
detectives located and recovered a black in color Smith & Wesson M&P Shield 9mm loaded with 7 rounds of 9mm ammunition
which was reported stolen out of Bellmawr New Jersey.
Jayden and the evidence were transported to the Wilmington Police Department.
Davonte was charged accordingly.
Jayden was processed on his VOP and charged accordingly. An Admin warrant was issued by probation for Jayden’s new charges.
Elija was charged accordingly. He has an active warrant and is awaiting extradition to be transported to DE

On January 3rd 2022 hours, 13A (Osler / Diaz) conducted a motor vehicle stop for a registration violation in the area
of the 4499 block of Governor Printz Blvd. When officers contacted the operator (Tazz Hicks BM 09/30/93), they observed that he was wearing an empty holster. Officers inquired if the defendant had a firearm in the vehicle, at which the defendant stated he was not sure if there was one in the vehicle. Officers removed the defendant from the vehicle and placed him into custody. The defendant then
admitted there was Marijuana in the vehicle. Officers conducted a vehicle search at which time they located a black in color Ruger Security 9mm loaded with 15 rounds in the center console of the vehicle along with two additional magazines in the trunk. A small amount of Marijuana (.9 grams) was also located on the passenger seat along with a black in color Machete located in the rear driver side passenger seat. The defendant was transported to central where he was charged appropriately. Officers conducted an NCIC check on the defendant which lists him as a person prohibited of carrying a firearm due to a failure to appear out of Ohio, stemming from a felony concealed carry weapons charge out of Dayton County Sheriff’s Office. The defendant may also be prohibited of carrying a firearm due to a contempt violation of a domestic violence protective order out of the state of New Jersey. The defendant pled guilty to the charge on 08/21/15 in Municipal Court of Bridgeton, NJ. It should be noted that the listed defendant was wanted out of Ohio for firearm offenses, however they refused to extradite

On Tuesday December 13th 1200 hours, SCU Officers observed Raiys Muhammed BM 07/26/2003 exit out of 714 E. 11th St. Officers were aware the defendant possessed several hard warrants for his arrest and approached him based on same. The defendant was taken into custody without incident and found to be in possession of 2.2 grams of marijuana. Additionally, Investigators observed the defendant on Instagram possessing two firearms on two separate occasions in the month of December. Officers held the residence pending a search warrant and executed same.  Located inside the defendant’s bedroom:
•        tan/black in color Polymer 80 9mm handgun
•        silver/black in color S&W 9mm handgun (#FDY0296) – reported stolen out of NCCPD on 10/28/22 (32-22-083181)
•        (3) extended magazines 
•        (1) 9mm magazine 
•        (73) rounds of 9mm ammunition
•        (39.03) grams of marijuana
not in gunstat meeting reports

On March 19th, 2024, at approximately 1157 hours, a ShotSpotter alert was received for seven rounds in the 700 Block of E. 22nd Street, followed by a second alert for five rounds in the same location. Upon the Officer's arrival in the area, they were approached by residents of 2118 N. Church Street that there was a victim of a shooting inside the residence. Officers located the victim (Javar Wright BM 09/17/06) on the second floor inside of the bathroom. It was learned that the victim was taking a shower and was stuck in the left thigh by a projectile that came through a second-floor window. The victim was transported to the Christiana Hospital, where he is listed in stable condition. The scene was located at the intersection of 22nd and Spruce Streets, which consisted of (47) 9mm spent shell casings and two struck unoccupied vehicles. Tomas Edison Elementary School also sustained damage to an office window from gunfire. A subject was inside the office at the time of the incident but was not injured. 

A witness was located who advised that they observed two black males armed with handguns enter a vehicle that was parked in front of their residence. The witness provided a partial registration (381077) and stated that their video surveillance captured what they observed. CID obtained the footage of what appeared to be a light-colored sedan speeding off after two subjects jumped in the rear. CID conducted an LPR search, which yielded a 1996 light-blue Grand Marquis Delaware Temporary registration XF381077, registered to Paul Murray Jr BM 05/09/2000, who resides at 1533 E. 28th Street. Approximately 45 minutes after the incident was initially reported, CID responded to the address and located the vehicle parked in front. Paul Murray was observed exiting the vehicle and entering the residence. Surveillance footage was obtained by TRU, which showed the vehicle entering the area at 1201 approximately 4 min after the shooting.

Surveillance was maintained at the residence, and assistance was requested from the DOCV to take over surveillance. CMTT was activated, and Murray exited the residence with his dog while CMTT was responding. Murray was taken into custody and was in possession of a cellular phone. CMTT executed the search warrant and the following items were located during the search of the residence;  

1)	Black in color Glock 19 Gen 5 9mm firearm (Serial No. BZP9780) with a magazine and 20 rounds of 9mm ammunition.
2)	Box of 50 9mm rounds of ammunition
3)	Black Blue Line Pump 12 Gauge Shotgun with 32 rounds of ammunition (Serial No. BLS00008691)
4)	$14,849 USC              

Murray was transported to Central, where an interview was conducted post-Miranda. Murray provided several versions of events but ultimately stated that three subjects approached him for a ride outside of his residence. Murray stated that he knew one only by the nickname “T” and claimed not to know the other two. He stated he believes “T” lives in the block but couldn’t say which residence. He stated that “T” asked for a ride to his grandmother’s house on the city's north side. Murray agreed to give them a ride and dropped them off on Spruce Street. Prior to getting out, Murray stated, “T,” pulled down a mask over his face, and exited with the other two subjects. Murray stated that he believed something was going to happen, so he waited for them. Murray stated that he heard gunshots and, a short time later, observed the three subjects running back to the car. Murray stated that he reversed as they were getting in his car, and he responded back to the Riverside area, where he dropped the three subjects off and responded to his residence. Murray stated that he did not observe the subjects in his car to have firearms.

On January 13, 2025, CGIC detectives were contacted by S/Cpl Geiser regarding an incident (25-2902) involving
the defendant, Ronald Stewart (05/14/1965), in the 4200 block of North Market St where he displayed a firearm during a
confrontation with a store clerk. TRU was notified and obtained the video surveillance of the incident.
CGIC detectives conducted an investigation into the incident at which point they applied for and were granted a search warrant for
Ronald’s residence, 119 Casimir Dr.
On January 14th, surveillance was established on 119 Casimir Drive at which point Ronald was observed exiting the residence and
entering his vehicle. Contact was made with Ronald where he was detained without incident.
CGIC, with the assistance of Safe Streets, executed the search warrant at the residence at which point they located and recovered a
black in color Bersa Thunder 380 caliber firearm (S/N #K49639) loaded with 7 rounds of 380 ammunition, 50 rounds of 22
caliber ammunition, and clothing from the initial incident.
Ronald and the evidence were transported to the Wilmington Police Department.
Name: Ronald Stewart
SBI: 00170124

On September 12, 2024 at approximately 1545 hours, members of Safe Streets stopped a gray in color Honda Accord
(CA: 8SGP564) in the 300 block of N. Madison Street for a traffic violation. During the course of the stop, officers removed the front
passenger, Caleb Coleman (10/22/2000) from the vehicle, at which point they recovered a loaded Smith and Wesson 9mm handgun
(#FZU1799) from his waistband. The driver, Paul Waller (06/02/1987) was removed from the vehicle as well and found to be in
possession of a loaded Beretta .45 caliber handgun (#PK31803) that was concealed in a fanny pack that was draped across his chest.
Both suspects were taken into custody without incident; neither of the defendants had permits to conceal firearms.

On October 23, 2025, at approximately 1548 hours, members of the Downtown Unit responded to Water and Shipley
Street for a report of a person with a gun on a DART bus. Witnesses on the bus advised an individual, identified as Jowan Whitley
(06/18/1999) appeared to be in possession of a firearm. Officers responded to the Transit Center to locate the bus, which was clear. Cpl.
Vazquez then observed Whitley sitting at the bus stop at the intersection of S. Market Street and Rosa Parks Drive. Whitley noticed
officers and began to walk away; however, contact was quickly made. For officer safety, officers then pat Whitley down, which is when
they recovered a loaded Glock 48 9mm (SN#BXCY313) handgun in his waistband. Whitley was placed into custody without incident.

On Wednesday October 5th 2154 hours, Safe Streets officers conducted a motor vehicle stop in the 300 block of
Concord Avenue for equipment and moving violations. During the stop, the officers smelled marijuana coming from within the
vehicle, removed the driver (Pierre Wright) and conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle. During the search, officers located a
Taurus G3 9mm firearm loaded with 10 live rounds of 9mm ammunition concealed in the driver’s side door pocket and
approximately 19 grams of marijuana in the center console. The firearm was submitted to FSU for processing along with a Test Fire
Request form. Post Miranda, Wright confessed to purchasing the firearm and carrying same concealed in his waistband just prior to
officers stopping his vehicle. Wright stated he carried the firearm for protection because he was coming from a rough part of the city

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 2145 hours, Officer Stewart was monitoring Instagram Live, where Officer Stewart observed the defendant, Naji Armstrong (09/26/2007), display a firearm on the live social media feed and then conceal the weapon in the front waistband of his pants. Shortly thereafter, Officer Stewart responded to the area of W. 4th Street and N. Franklin Street, a location the officer knows the defendant frequents. Upon noticing Officer Stewart, the defendant began behaving suspiciously, attempting to conceal himself behind parked vehicles on the block. Officer Stewart alerted assisting officers and coordinated a stop of the defendant. The defendant ultimately attempted to evade the officers by entering the Franklin Deli and Grocery at 1232 W. 4th Street.
Inside the store, Officer Stewart detained the defendant and recovered a loaded Glock 23 .40 (S/N #CCFE653) firearm from his front waistband.

On Sunday May 5th at approximately 2023 hours, ShotSpotter alerted consecutively for one round at 2412 and one round at 2413 N. Washington Street. Arriving officers located the victim, Quadre Guinn BM/ 10/31/1997, lying in the roadway in front of 2413 with the defendant, Demi Lee BF/ 12/27/2000, on top of him, still actively fighting the victim. The victim's mother was also actively attempting to separate Lee from Guinn. Next to the defendant and victim was a Smith and Wesson 9mm semi-auto handgun missing the magazine and two spent 9mm casings. Guinn sustained a gunshot wound to his left hip area. He was transported to CER and is listed as stable. Detectives Rook and Stallings responded to CER to interview the victim; however, he was taken to surgery, and a statement could not be obtained at this time. While at CER, Detectives were able to obtain a statement from the victim’s mother, Alexis Guinn who was cooperative but did not see the suspect shoot the victim. Detective Merced was notified by Officers that the missing magazine to the 9mm handgun was located in the rear of the police vehicle that transported the suspect. The magazine was collected, photographed, and entered into evidence. 
 At 0245 hours, Lee was transported to central after being treated at WER. Detective Merced conducted an interview with her and she admitted to shooting the victim in the leg during a physical altercation. Lee claimed that the victim who she does not know was attempting to rob her which caused the altercation. She stated that after she shot the victim, the two of them began to struggle over the gun, and the magazine came out. She stated that she shoved the magazine in her pants and later told officers that she discarded it in the police vehicle. Search warrants were authored and executed to obtain a DNA sample from Lee as well as the clothing she was wearing during the incident. Detective Merced obtained an arrest warrant for Demy Lee for Assault 1st, PFDCF, PFBPP and Discharge Firearm on Street.

During the month of May 2022, Det. Alava initiated an investigation into Rakim DIXON for drug sales in the area of
10th & Kirkwood Street. On May 12, 2022, Det. Alava conducted a vehicle stop on Rakim DIXON at 11th & Spruce Street resulting in
the seizure of a small amount of drugs. Rakim DIXON was charged accordingly and received a bail of $2,000 secure. This case is
currently pending, 30-22-32567.
At the start of January 2023, Det. Alava again received information regarding Rakim DIXON engaged in drug sales and initiated an
investigation into same for Crack Cocaine sales at 2424 Bowers Street, Wilmington.
On January 18, 2023, members of the Vice Unit and K9 located Rakim DIXON at 10th & Bennett Street where he was detained
without incident. Members of the DOCV and K9 responded to and executed a search warrant at 2424 Bowers Street where the
following items were located and seized:
• Black Taurus G2C 9mm semi-automatic handgun, #ACA435257 (29N) containing 15 rounds of 9mm ammunition
• 14.6 grams of Crack Cocaine
• 4.914 grams of Heroin stamped “Cock”
• 176.9 grams of Marijuana

On Thursday September 14th at approximately 1508 hours, 11C (Downing) was dispatched and responded to 604
North Walnut Street in reference to a Property Found complaint. Upon arrival, this officer made contact with the reporting
person/Security Officer who advised at approximately 1510 hours he conducted a property check of the Church interior and exterior at
which time he observed a Purple book bag located outside in a ditch which contained a black in color firearm and other miscellaneous
items. The RP advised prior to Police arrival, an unknown male wearing all black with a red and black checker shirt, light skin in
complexion, later identified as (Quazeem Rosa 08/13/1996) returned to the front of the building and began asking them if a purple
book bag was located at which time they replied "no". Rosa responded to the rear of the church from the window and stayed in the
area to continue to look for same before leaving the area. Officers conducted a check of the book bag while on scene at which time a
black in color Taurus GX4 9mm with attached magazine containing (8) rounds and (1) round in the chamber were located inside.
It should be noted, (4) extra 9mm rounds were located inside a black pouch which was also inside of the purple book bag. Also located
inside the bag was Marijuana (19g), numerous paraphernalia items, a social security card for Quazeem Rosa and a work ID card. It
should be noted, during these interviews, Rosa responded back to the front door of the church at which time this officer was advised of
same. This officer responded outside to the front door and then placed Rosa in custody. Rosa admitted that the purple book bag,
firearm, and marijuana belong to him
