case_summary:
On Monday March 21, 2022 1602 hours, Tiffany Righter BF 07/27/85 responded to central to report a domestic incident involving a firearm. The victim reported that she and her boyfriend, Sebastian Corbin, were involved in an argument on March 18th at her residence located at 500 N Clayton St. During the course of the argument, Corbin threatened the victim with a knife and firearm. The victim advised she locked herself inside of a bathroom before fleeing the residence. The victim advised that she returned to the residence around 11:00AM the following day where she observed Corbin asleep with the handgun next to him. The victim took the gun to her mother’s residence where she locked same in a safe before responding to Central to report the incident. The victim filmed the incident on her cellphone and provided same to officers. 

Sebastian Corbin was taken into custody on Saturday May 14th around 12:40AM while attempting to enter his ex-girlfriends residence.

On Monday, December 15, 2025, at approximately 1727 hours, Officer Farrell was on a proactive patrol in the 1000 block of Spruce Street when she observed a Dodge Caravan with a fictitious registration. A vehicle stop was conducted in the 1200 block of Northeast Boulevard without incident. The driver, Shmaar Harris (11/15/1982) and passenger, Sharif Elsayed (09/03/2000) were asked
to exit the vehicle after they were unable to provide vehicle registration, proof of insurance, as well as valid identification. At this time, Elsayed was pat down for officer safety, and found to be in possession of a concealed, loaded Taurus PT145 .45 caliber
(SN#NCW19522) handgun, as well as 8 grams of Marijuana and drug paraphernalia on his person. Elsayed was transported back to Central and charged accordingly.

On Monday April 10th, Officers Stewart and Linkhorst signed an arrest warrant for Zion Miller BM 02/20/2003 for
Robbery 1st and related charges. During that incident, Miller reportedly displayed a firearm to the victim and forcibly removed the victim’s jewelry, USC, and car keys prior to fleeing the area (30-23-27033). On Friday April 14th 2005 hours, Officers Stewart and Linkhorst were actively monitoring Miller’s Instagram Live. During that time, the officers observed Miller display a black in color firearm on the live feed. The officers were also able to identify Miller’s location from the live feed and coordinated a stop of Miller with assisting officers. Officers located Miller in the 200 block of Stroud Street and placed him into custody without incident. Incident to arrest, Miller was found to be in possession of a small amount of marijuana and a couple Oxycodone pills. The officers conducted a retrace of Miller’s direction of travel and located a Ruger LCP .380 firearm loaded with 4 rounds in the magazine and 1 in the chamber (reported stolen to NCCPD). At the time of his arrest, Miller was wearing the victim’s chain from the robbery incident. A search warrant was obtained for Miller’s DNA to be compared to the firearm. Miller’s cell phone was also seized and pending a search warrant in furtherance of this investigation. Miller was transported to Central, where he was processed on his outstanding Robbery 1st warrant. Miller was also charged with PFBPP, PABPP, Receiving a Stolen Firearm, Tampering with Physical Evidence and Possession of Marijuana.

On Wednesday, September 25, 2024, at approximately 1455 hours, a ShotSpotter notification alerted for six (6) rounds
in the area of 1499 N Market, Wilmington, DE 19801. Officers responded to the area at which they observed three unknown subjects
running Northbound across the Market St Bridge away from the area of the shots fired. The subjects were detained and identified as
Jamere Mickens, (12/03/2008), Ray’jay Charles (02/04/2007), and Jakhyrun Koonce, (10/31/2007).
During a search of Mickens, a loaded Ruger Security .380 (SN #38709787), with rubber bands on the grip, was located. The loaded
firearm had three (3) .380 in the magazine and one (1) chambered.
The firearm was determined to be stolen out of WPD - July 31, 2024 – 200 blk of North Gray Ave, Wilmington, DE 19805 - Trenaya
Jackson (03/10/1999)

During August 2024, DOCV initiated an investigation into drug sales by Keith Berry (09/09/1988) from 210
Lower Oak Street, 1207 Pleasant Street, and the 200 block of N. Franklin Street. Through the course of this investigation, search
warrants were authored and obtained.
On September 19, 2024, at approximately 1105 hours, members of the Vice Unit, CGIC, & K9, conducted a vehicle stop on Berry
in the 400 block of S. Harrison Street without incident. The search warrants for 210 Lower Oak Street and 1207 Pleasant Street
were executed. While searching 210 Lower Oak St, officers located a Smith and Wesson MP Shield .40 (#JEL0437) loaded and
the magazine containing six (6) rounds. The following items were seized along with the handgun: .9 grams of Cocaine .406
grams of Heroin, 1.7 grams of Marijuana, 4 Amphetamine pills, 1 Alprazolam pill, 9mm, .22, and .40 caliber ammunition, and
$613.00 USC.

On Sunday March 31, 2024 at 1216 hours, Wilcom received a call (caller refused) in reference to a group of three
black male subjects dressed in all black with face masks walking southbound in the 1300 block of North Market Street. The caller
further advised one of the subjects was in possession of a firearm in a red book bag. While on an area canvass for the subjects, K9-14 (Dmeza) observed the group walking westbound in the 200 block of W. 11th Street. The defendants observed Dmeza and began
running southbound on Tatnall Street from W. 11th Street. The defendants continued south into a courtyard in the middle of 200 block
of West 10th Street. Dmeza quickly circled the block and observed the defendants running towards the TD Bank (300 Delaware
Avenue). A pedestrian stop of Artie Melton BM 11/05/2007 (still in possession of the red book bag) and Jerome Pegram BM
03/07/2007 was conducted. It should be noted the third suspect had continued walking westbound on West 11th Street when the
defendants fled from police and an area search yielded negative results for locating same. An area search through the courtyard was
conducted at which time a loaded Hi-Point 9mm (#P1318339) was located underneath a bush on the west side of the walkway.
Melton and Pegram were charged accordingly.

On Friday May 17th, 2024, CGIC Detectives responded to 1716 Lancaster Ave in reference to a Person with a Gun
call. Dispatch was able to provide a description of the suspect possessing the firearm as well as advised the suspect had placed the
firearm into a Louis Vuitton bag. Upon arrival to the area, Detectives observed 2 males sitting on the porch of the residence, one of
which matching the description. Upon seeing the detectives, both males began to walk away. Detectives were able to make contact
with both with the assistance of K9 Peterson and Cpl Hazzard. While making contact with the suspect, Zameer McMillian BM
01/14/1999, detectives observed what appeared to be crack cocaine hanging out of his sleeve at which point they attempted to take
him into custody. After a brief struggle, Zameer was placed into custody. Zameer was found in possession of approximately 2.7
grams of crack cocaine and approximately .224 grams of heroin. During a search of the area, Detectives located the Louis Vuitton bag
which contained a black and tan in color Glock 20 10mm handgun which was loaded with a total of 3 rounds of ammunition.
Zameer and the firearm were transported to Central. Detectives attempted to interview Zameer however he was uncooperative. A test
fire form was submitted.

On Thursday October 3, 2024, at approximately 1742 hours, 18-David (Officer Avery Stewart) was in the 200 block
of N. Dupont Street when he observed the defendant, James Mason Friend BM 07/17/2008, walking with a mask covering his face. Upon noticing the officer, the defendant attempted to conceal himself behind a parked vehicle. Officer Stewart exited his patrol vehicle and noticed the defendant abruptly grab at his front waistband, a behavior commonly associated with carrying a concealed firearm. Officer Stewart approached to make contact with the defendant, who immediately fled on foot. During the pursuit, Officer Stewart observed the defendant remove a firearm from his waistband and discard it in the 200 block of N. Scott Street. Shortly after, Officer Stewart apprehended the defendant without further incident. Assisting units recovered a loaded Glock 19 Gen5 9mm handgun (#CBNV911). The defendant was transported to Central where he admitted to possessing and discarding the firearm. He was subsequently charged with Possession of a Firearm by a Prohibited Person (Juvenile), Possession of Ammunition by a Prohibited Person (Juvenile), and Resisting Arrest.

On November 26, 2025 Detective Shea, with the assistance of Safe Streets and CID, executed a search warrant at 602 E. 23rd Street, in reference to an open homicide investigation. Upon entering the residence, Yahim Harris (10/24/2000) was located hiding in the basement and taken into custody without incident. Located within close proximity to Harris, officers located a lock box were a loaded Glock 30 .45 Caliber (SN#CBWB241) handgun. The firearm was equipped with a “switch” device making it capable of full
automatic operation. In the same box, officers located an additional loaded Glock 19 9mm (SN#CDYG377) handgun. Located in a second floor bedroom, which belonged to Jayvon Hale-Jones (04/08/2000), Detectives located clothing, and one Taurus
G3C 9mm (SN#AEJ666819) handgun. The firearm was equipped with a “switch” device making it capable of full automatic operation. Hale-Jones was not present inside the residence and efforts are underway to locate him.
Harris was transported to Central and was processed accordingly. The investigation is on-going.

On March 11, 2025 at approximately 1533 hours, CGIC investigators were in the area of E. 25 th and Thatcher Street
conducting surveillance for a firearm investigation when they observed William Brooks (11/26/2007) and two other unknown subjects.
Officers observed an object in Brooks’ waistband and attempted to make contact with the same. Brooks immediately fled on foot and was
was observed throwing a firearm in the rear yard of 1011 E. 22 nd St before being taken into custody. Officers recovered a black in color
Glock 29 10mm (S/N: CDUD525) firearm was loaded with one (1) 10mm round in the chamber. It should be noted that there was not a
magazine in the firearm; however a recanvas of Brooks’ path of flight, revealed the black in color mag

On Friday June 24th 2110 hours, Safe Streets officers conducted a motor vehicle stop in the 200 block of E. 4th St for
an equipment violation. During that time, contact was made with the driver, Tyair Worley. While making contact with Worley,
officers smelled marijuana coming from the vehicle and observed a magazine for a firearm in the center console cup holder. The
officers conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle and located a loaded Glock 19 9mm semiautomatic handgun which was located on the back floorboard of the vehicle along with (0.5 grams) of marijuana.

dealer_name: Bulllseye Indoor Range and Gun Shop
case_summary:
On December 07, 2022, Det. Cuadrado executed a search warrant at 120 E. 24th Street, Wilmington where
numerous types of drugs including a large quantity of Fentanyl (37 grams) were seized. 30-22-84671. At the start of January 2023,
Det. Cuadrado again received information regarding the occupants of the aforementioned location engaging in drug sales. Det.
Cuadrado initiated an investigation into Tashae Owens-Charles BF 09/09/1992 for Crack Cocaine sales at 120 E. 24th St. On
Tuesday January 10, 2023, members of the Vice Unit, OSS, and K9 executed a search warrant at 120 E. 24th Street, without incident.
The target of the investigation, Tashae OWENS-CHARLES was not present at the time of the execution. An arrest warrant and DNA
warrant was authored for Tashae Owens-Charles.
During a search of the residence, the listed items were located and seized:
• FN FNS9 9mm semi-automatic handgun, serial number (#GKU0050592) – reported stolen out of Chamblee PD, Georgia.
Extended magazine containing 23 rounds of 9mm ammunition
• 81.7 grams of loose & packed Fentanyl / Heroin (Approximately 40,850 doses)
• 18.2 grams of Crack Cocaine
• 27.1 grams of Marijuana
• 17 Xanax pills
• 31 Suboxone strips
• Drug Paraphernalia
Tashae Owens-Charles was taken into custody by DOCV on January 18th in the 2200 block of N. Pine St.

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
2. On Thursday, May 29, 2025, at approximately 1423 hours, CGIC Detectives were contacted by Pltm. Hutt regarding a
possible robbery/assault which has occurred. Pltm. Hutt advised the victim was “pistol whipped” and robbed by a female and her friends
at 608 N. Washington St. (25-038909). Detectives are familiar with the residence and its occupants at which time they began responding
to the area to conduct surveillance. As Detectives were arriving in the area, Muhammad Means (03/28/2005) and Emanual Cooper (01/30/2006) were observed exiting the
residence. Both individuals had a bag in their possession, they then entered a tan Toyota Camry. Detectives surveilled the vehicle to the
area of 12th and West, at which point a vehicle stop was conducted. While initiating the stop, Cooper attempted to exit the rear passenger
side of the vehicle to flee, however, detectives immediately made contact and were able to detain him. While detain him, a black in color
Canik TP9 SFX (SN: 21-BC36622) 9mm handgun partially fell from his waistband, where it was immediately recovered. Means was the
removed from the vehicle and detained. During a search of the rear seats, detectives located and recovered a black in color Taurus GX4
(SN: AEL831179) 9mm handgun, which was found under the driver’s seat. In addition, detectives located the bags that both individuals
were originally carrying, the bags were found to contain a total of 94.2 grams of marijuana. Both subjects were transported to Central

On Saturday December 3rd 1930 hours, Safe Streets officers conducted a motor vehicle stop in the 200 block of N.
Broom St, for an equipment violation. While approaching the vehicle, the officers observed Cornelius Archy BM 06/14/1989,
abruptly jump from the front passenger area of the vehicle into the rear passenger seat of the vehicle.
The officers then made contact with the driver, Kimysha Archy BF 09/21/1989 and Cornelius Archy (rear passenger). During the
contact, the officers smelled an odor of marijuana coming from within the vehicle and a probable cause search was conducted. During
the search, the officers located a black duffle bag in the back seat of the vehicle containing a Glock 19 9mm semiautomatic handgun
(#BVGY476) and an extended magazine containing 30 rounds of ammunition. The bag was located directly behind the rear passenger
seat, where Cornelius was seated inside of the vehicle. Also inside of the bag, the officers located all male clothing, a TWIC card
bearing the name Cornelius Archy, and casino receipts also bearing his name. Officers also located (32.5 grams) of marijuana inside
the driver’s door pocket.
Cornelius is prohibited from owning/ possessing a firearm due to multiple prior violent felony convictions. At the time of this arrest,
Cornelius was on pretrial supervision as a result of a pending attempted murder 1st charge and related felony weapon charges
stemming from an arrest in October of 2020.
Both Cornelius and Kimysha were placed into police custody without incident and transported to Central. At Central, DNA was
obtained from both of the Defendants.

On Saturday May 28th 2242 hours, A Platoon officer Crumlish conducted a vehicle stop in the 1100 block of Bennett
St for illegal window tint and illegal U-turn. Upon approaching the vehicle, Ptlm. Crumlish detected a strong odor of marijuana
coming from inside the vehicle. The driver and sole occupant of the vehicle, Cleveland Williams, admitted to possessing marijuana
and was asked to exit the vehicle. Williams then advised that there was a loaded firearm concealed in the center console. A search of
the vehicle revealed a loaded Ruger 9mm handgun in a black holster located inside the center console. Mr. Williams was also found to
be in possession of (7.0 grams) of marijuana.
Name: Cleveland Williams
SBI: 00980290
DOB: 09/27/1994
Age: 27
Address: 102 Duke Dr., New Castle, DE 19720
Gang Affiliation: None Known
Probation: No
Person Prohibited: No
Offender History:
No prior Criminal History
Charges: CCDW, Poss MJ
Bail: $2,650 unsecured
DOC Status: Released No Supervision
Preliminary Hearing: 06/13/22

On November 26, 2024 at approximately 1905 hours, Officers Cannon and Bond were on proactive patrol in the area
of 800 W. 8th St when they observed a grey Honda Accord (DE 900710) operating with illegal window and failed to utilize a turn
signal. A traffic stop was initiated and officers were able to make contact with the driver, Tysheeka Johnson BF 02/04/1993. Officers
asked Johnson if there were any firearms in the vehicle, to which she responded “no.” Officers observed a brown purse on the
floorboard of the rear passenger side. After running a DELJIS inquiry on Johnson and returning back to the Honda, officers noticed
that the brown purse had been moved to the rear driver side floorboard. At this time, Johnson was asked to step out of the vehicle and
consented for officers to search the vehicle. Officers Cannon and Bond located (5) grams of crack cocaine and a loaded Glock 43
9mm (#AGSW135) which was concealed under the driver’s seat. Johnson was taken into custody and charged accordingly.

On Thursday June 23rd 1930 hours, B Platoon officers responded to 1128 Pleasant St in reference to a man armed
with a gun. Upon arrival, officers made contact with Douglas Bush, who was on the roof of his residence where he advised officers
that he was armed. Officer Osler asked Bush to come down which he complied without incident. A pat down frisk for weapons was
conducted which met with negative results. Bush advised that he was being threatened by people in the neighborhood which led to
him arming himself. Officers conducted a DELJIS inquiry on Bush which revealed that he is a person prohibited from possessing both
firearms and ammunition as a result of a violent felony conviction (assault 2nd). Officers executed a search warrant and removed (15)
firearms along with ammunition and magazines which were located inside of a gun safe in a second story bedroom. Two additional
firearms were recovered from the roof of the residence where officers initially saw Bush, and where he told officers that he was
armed.

On Wednesday April 12th 0047 hours, D Platoon officers responded to the area of 1 S. Monroe Street in reference to
a person with a gun complaint. Contact was made with the victim (Ellington) who stated just prior to officers arrival, a white 1997
Ford F150 (DE XF329058) occupied by both defendants pulled over to the side of the road just ahead of where he and several of his
friends were walking. The driver (Eddie Foster BM 07/14/1990) exited the vehicle with a shotgun in his hand and racked the weapon
one time. The victim immediately called 911 at which time Foster re-entered the vehicle and left the area. The victim advised officers
that one of his friends had been involved in a verbal argument with both defendants shortly before this incident. An area search was
conducted and the vehicle was located, parked in the 200 block of N. Monroe Street. A Deljis inquiry of the vehicle registration
revealed the registered owner’s address to be 202 N. Monroe Street. Eddie Foster was located at that residence and a short time later
Joseph Bowe BM 03/23/1989 returned on foot back to the 200 block of N. Monroe Street. A show up was conducted and the victim
positively identified both defendants, who were taken into custody without incident. During the course of the investigation, Foster
openly admitted to having the shotgun in his truck and exiting the vehicle with same during the incident. Foster consented to a search
of his vehicle and the shotgun was retrieved (Mossberg 12 gauge shotgun loaded with one 20 gauge slug round) and one additional
20 gauge slug round was located inside the truck. The above listed defendants were charged accordingly.

In response to recent acts of violence in District 13, DOCV Det. Alava initiated a drug investigation into Wayne
REESE selling Crack Cocaine from 35 E. 24th Street, Wilmington, DE. On Thursday September 15th 1324 hours, members of the
Vice Unit and K9 executed the search warrant at 35 E. 24th Street, without incident. During a search of the residence, the listed items
were located and seized.
• Accutek AT .380 caliber semi-automatic handgun, serial # 014681, (29N), loaded with a total of 6 rounds of .380 caliber
ammunition.
• Single shot 12 gauge shotgun, serial # 13882, (29N). Loaded with one round of 12 gauge ammunition.
• 50.6 grams of Cocaine
• 21.2 grams of Crack Cocaine
• 1 gram of Heroin
• 7 MDMA / ecstasy pills.
• 42.3 grams of Marijuana.
• Various types of ammunition and a handgun holster.
• $760.00 USC.
• Drug Paraphernalia.

On Thursday November 10th 1222 hours, SCU Investigators were in the 1500 block of W. 4th Street when they
observed the defendant Gibson, Laandrea (BM 07/04/1991) and Gibbs, Devante (BM 05/09/2002) look back and observed the
approaching Street Crime’s vehicle and quickened their pace and walked into the (Hispanic American and Mexican Food J&R
Market). Street Crime Investigators made contact with Gibson and Gibbs who were observed separating from one another into
different sections of the store. Upon making contact with Gibson, he was observed displaying characteristics of an armed gunman by
pushing an unknown object in his waistband and blading his body. Investigators asked if the defendant was in possession of a firearm
and consented to being pat down. During the pat down, Investigators recovered a loaded (CANIK TP9SA 9mm Firearm containing
(1) live round in the chamber and (15) 9mm rounds in the magazine concealed in Gibson’s waistband. The firearm’s serial
T647221AP0388 was checked locally and NCIC and found to be negative. Gibson was checked on Deljis and found to have an active
capias for his arrest. The defendant was taken into custody without incident and found to be in possession of 1 gram of crack cocaine,
26.3 grams of marijuana, 4 Alprazolam pills, 28 Suboxone tablets. Additional Street Crimes Investigators made contact with Suspect 1
Gibbs, Devante (BM 05/09/2002) and was checked on Deljis. Gibbs was found to have 4 active Capias for his arrest. 1 Capias was
observed to be for a CCDW charge for failing to appear. Gibbs was found to be wearing blue LATEX gloves. Gibbs was taken into
custody and processed on his outstanding capiases. It should also be noted, Gibbs is a known (NorthPak Member)

On July 1st 1108 hours, Officers were dispatched to 1108 E. 15th St in reference to a terroristic threatening complaint
where the suspect was armed with a firearm inside the residence. Officers arrived on scene, established a perimeter, and were able to
have the residents exit through the front door. A short time later, the suspect, Marion Woodard, also exited through the front door,
unarmed. Through the course of investigation it was determined that Woodard had threatened his father and nephew while armed with
a long gun. The residence was searched and located inside the second floor bedroom of Woodard Sr. was a Marlin model 60m .22
caliber rifle. Woodard Jr was transported to WER where he was committed to the CAPES unit for psychiatric treatment. Woodard is
an eleven time convicted felon and on probation restitution only. A warrant was obtained against Woodard for Aggravated Menacing,
PFDCF, PFBPP and Terroristic Threatening.

On Thursday June 23rd 1930 hours, B Platoon officers responded to 1128 Pleasant St in reference to a man armed
with a gun. Upon arrival, officers made contact with Douglas Bush, who was on the roof of his residence where he advised officers
that he was armed. Officer Osler asked Bush to come down which he complied without incident. A pat down frisk for weapons was
conducted which met with negative results. Bush advised that he was being threatened by people in the neighborhood which led to
him arming himself. Officers conducted a DELJIS inquiry on Bush which revealed that he is a person prohibited from possessing both
firearms and ammunition as a result of a violent felony conviction (assault 2nd). Officers executed a search warrant and removed (15)
firearms along with ammunition and magazines which were located inside of a gun safe in a second story bedroom. Two additional
firearms were recovered from the roof of the residence where officers initially saw Bush, and where he told officers that he was
armed.
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Monday January 22, 2024 @ 1505 hours, NCCPD MET Officers were conducting surveillance in the 400 block of South Harrison St when they observed Vaughna Moore BM 01/07/1974 park his Acura MDX in front of 421 S. Harrison St, get out of the vehicle and approach 4 juveniles. Moore was then observed brandishing a black in color firearm which caused the juveniles to flee the area.  Moore got back into his vehicle and drove away until NCCPD stopped the vehicle and called for WPD to assist with the arrest.

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On June 17, 2015, members of the DOCV were conducting surveillance at 1110 Maple St, in regard to a Citizen Drug Complaint.
Shortly after establishing surveillance, officers observed a subject, Donald Saunders (07/04/1996) exiting the residence carrying a black bag and respond to 119 S. Harrison St. (Chestnut Liquors). Saunders entered the store with the bag and soon exited without it. Officers then observed Saunders meet with subject, Christopher Williams (12/04/1995) and conduct an open air hand to hand transaction. At this time Saunders and Williams were stopped for the drug investigation. Saunders and Williams were taken into custody without incident. Officers then responded back to Chestnut Liquors and located the black bag, which Saunders had hid in the store. In the bag, officers located one black in color Ruger LCP .380 (S/N: 371245436) handgun loaded with six (6) rounds of .380 caliber casings.
At Central, Saunders admitted to being in possession of 4.63 grams of Crack Cocaine, he then admitted to selling Crack Cocaine and possessing the found firearm, which he claims to have purchased on the streets approximately one month ago. Williams was found to be possession of 1.04 grams of Crack Cocaine. Both defendants were charged accordingly.

On Wednesday October 4th at approximately 1208 hours, Det. Deveraux initiated surveillance on Omar Brown BM 02/09/1986 in the area of Taylor & Kirkwood St and observed him conduct a hand-to-hand drug transaction. The buyer was followed out of the area, stopped, and found to possess a quantity of Crack Cocaine. During the course of surveillance, Omar Brown was observed operating and utilizing a vehicle for his drug transactions. Brown was stopped without incident and transported to Central along with his vehicle. While enroute, Brown attempted to destroy a small package of Crack Cocaine in the back of the police vehicle. Det. Deveraux authored and obtained a search warrant for Brown’s vehicle. A black in color S&W M&P 9mm semi-automatic handgun (#RJX0152) was located in the vehicle. The handgun was reported stolen out of Reading Pennsylvania jurisdiction. The firearm as well as the Test Fire Form was submitted to FSU for processing. DNA was obtained from Brown.

On February 18, 2025, CGIC detectives were traveling Westbound in the 400 block of E. 4th St. when they observed two known subjects, Kwahlik Hopkins-Bey (03/13/2006) and Shakye Johnson (04/04/2008) walking Westbound on the sidewalk. Detectives were aware the Hopkins-Bey had an outstanding capias by NCC Family Court.
As officers made contact, they asked Hopkins-Bey if he had anything in his possession, to which he said no. Upon making contact, detectives felt a metal object concealed in the left interior pocket of his jacket. At this time, detectives located a black in color Taurus G3C 9mm (S/N: ADA872682) loaded with one (1) round in the chamber and nine (9) rounds in the magazine.
Hopkins-Bey was taken into custody without incident and transported to Central.

On Friday September 23rd 1245 hours, Safe Streets observed Xavier Broomer in the 700 block of West 6th Street,
occupying the driver’s seat of a Honda Accord. The officers conducted a Deljis inquiry of Broomer which determined that he had an
active capias for his arrest. The officers exited their police vehicle and approached the Honda to make contact with Broomer
regarding his capias. Upon being approached by officers, Broomer immediately exited his vehicle. While making contact with
Broomer, the officers smelled marijuana coming from within the vehicle. Officers placed Broomer into custody and then conducted a
probable cause search of his vehicle. During the search, the officers located a loaded Springfield Armory .40 caliber handgun loaded
with 9 rounds of ammunition in the magazine and 1 round in the chamber. The officers located the firearm in the glovebox of the
vehicle along with paperwork belonging to Broomer, a work identification card belonging to Broomer, and a clear plastic bag
containing 77 Oxycodone pills. Officers also located a marijuana grinder containing approximately .5 grams of marijuana under the
passenger seat of the vehicle

On Tuesday July 19th 2337 hours, A Platoon Officers Wilkers/Bond were in the area of 300 W. 7th St when they
observed Lamar Seth sitting in a chair in front of 302 W. 7th St smoking marijuana. Officers noted that they had prior confrontations
with Seth who is known to be extremely aggressive and combative. Officers exited their vehicle, employed their CEW and began
giving Seth commands to not move and put his hands up. While Seth was still sitting in his chair, officers briefly began to conduct a
search of his person when they felt a firearm located in his left pant leg. Officers then began to give Seth more commands to stand up
and put his hands behind his back which he failed to comply. Seth then began to flee into the house at which time officers deployed
their CEW striking Seth in his back, but had negative results. Seth was able to enter the residence and was taken into custody after a
brief struggle. After handcuffing Seth, officers began to help him to his feet at which point a black in color Hi-Point 9mm handgun fell
out of his shorts. Seth was also found to be in possession of (1 gram) of marijuana and (0.056 grams) of heroin.

On November 26, 2025 Detective Shea, with the assistance of Safe Streets and CID, executed a search warrant at 602 E. 23rd Street, in reference to an open homicide investigation. Upon entering the residence, Yahim Harris (10/24/2000) was located hiding in the basement and taken into custody without incident. Located within close proximity to Harris, officers located a lock box were a loaded Glock 30 .45 Caliber (SN#CBWB241) handgun. The firearm was equipped with a “switch” device making it capable of full
automatic operation. In the same box, officers located an additional loaded Glock 19 9mm (SN#CDYG377) handgun. Located in a second floor bedroom, which belonged to Jayvon Hale-Jones (04/08/2000), Detectives located clothing, and one Taurus
G3C 9mm (SN#AEJ666819) handgun. The firearm was equipped with a “switch” device making it capable of full automatic operation. Hale-Jones was not present inside the residence and efforts are underway to locate him.
Harris was transported to Central and was processed accordingly. The investigation is on-going.

On Wednesday May 25th 0052 hours, A Platoon officers (Wilkers/Bond) conducted a motor vehicle stop in the 600
block of W. 4th St for speeding violation and heavy window tint. As officers approached the vehicle, they detected an odor of burnt marijuana coming from the vehicle. Officers made contact with the sole occupant of the vehicle, Wayne Barksdale, and observed multiple small partially consumed marijuana cigars in the ashtray in the center console. Barksdale was asked to step out of the vehicle and a probable cause search was conducted. During the search, officers located the following:
• A loaded Glock 43X 9mm handgun located under the driver’s seat
• (17) MDMA tablets
• Glock magazine containing (10) rounds
• Marijuana cigar (.5 grams)
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Thursday October 3, 2024, at approximately 0136 hours, WPD officers were in the 1200 block of Northeast Blvd when they observed a vehicle traveling southbound in the northbound lane. The vehicle then violates several traffic violations and an attempt to stop the vehicle was conducted. After a brief pursuit, the suspect vehicle collides with the guard rai and two suspects exit the vehicle and flee on foot. Dawone Stewart BM 03/20/2002 (driver) and D’vonte Williams BM 05/11/2001 (passenger) were quickly apprehended and taken into custody. During a preliminary search of the vehicle, officers located a Glock 19 9mm semi-automatic handgun (SN #BFFB951) with a magazine containing eight (8) 9mm rounds of ammunition. The firearm was located on the driver’s side floorboard in plain view. During a search surrounding the vehicle, a Glock 22 .40 caliber semi-automatic handgun (SN #BTSC701) with a magazine containing eleven (11) .40 rounds of ammunition and one (1) chambered was located. Stewart was charged with PFBPP and Title 21 offenses. Williams was charged with Resisting. A firearm offense is pending further investigation. 
 **It should be noted that both guns recovered were reported to be stolen during a robbery on 10/2/24 – victim late reported robbery on 10/3/22 – WPD Report # 30-24-074896**

On Wednesday April 20th 2120 hours, Safe Streets assisted P&P with an admin search regarding a Level 3
Probationer, Andre Pierce BM 10/10/02.
Located inside the residence:
Andre Pierce BM 10/10/02
Candra Bryant BF 06/01/86 (Andre’s mother)
Dahmir Cooper BM 01/08/08
Rahmir Pierce BM 07/31/13
Athier Pierce BM 04/24/15
Ja’Cier Pierce BM 03/14/21
Items seized during the search:
Marijuana (25 grams) – located in the defendant’s shirt pocket Glock 22 handgun (loaded with 21 rounds of .40cal ammunition inside an extended magazine) – located in the defendant’s bedroom
One live 9mm round – located in the defendant’s bedroom
Marijuana (3.2 grams) – located in the laundry room behind the defendant’s bedroom
Glock 19 handgun (loaded with 18 rounds of 9mm ammunition inside an extended magazine) – located in a toddler’s bedroom closet
Century Arms Rifle (with an empty magazine) – located in the back yard of the residence inside a green/back duffle bag
Two cellphones
During a post Miranda interview, Andre Pierce confessed to possessing the marijuana and stated that one of the handguns was his, but
he did not specify which handgun. He also confessed that ‘the big one is mine”, referring to the rifle. He also confessed to knowing
where it was found in the back of the residence outside by the garage.
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Wednesday July 6th 1445 hours, SCU Officers were in the 700 block of E. 4th St when they observed the
defendant exiting Taffy’s convenience store, possessing what appeared to be the imprint of a firearm concealed in his left front pant
pocket. Officers approached the defendant and asked him if he had a firearm in his pocket to which he replied, “Yes”. He was then
asked if he possessed a valid CCDW permit, which he did not, and was taken into custody. Officers removed a loaded SCCY CPX-2
9mm handgun from the defendants pant pocket. The defendant has no DE criminal history and advised he was from PA.

On Friday July 14th at approximately 2000 hours, members of Safe Streets were on proactive patrol in the West Center City area when they observed Char-Quan Banks BM 08/18/1998 riding an electric bike westbound on a sidewalk in the 700 block of W. 5th St.  Officers activated the police vehicle’s emergency lights and siren in attempt to stop Banks, however, he fled from officers on the electric bike.  Officers pursued Banks to 5th and Madison Streets where he began to manipulate a fanny pack style bag that was draped over his chest.  Fearing he was attempting to produce a firearm, an officer deployed his CEW, causing Banks to drop the bag and fall to the ground at 5th and Madison Streets.  Banks was taken into custody without further incident.  Officers quickly recovered the bag and found it to contain a Smith & Wesson .40 caliber handgun (#PBE8874) as well as 62.3 grams of marijuana.  Banks was transported to Wilmington Hospital where he was treated for the CEW exposure as well as abrasions and a broken left wrist.  Banks was transported to Central where he was booked on the firearm charges.  Banks was on level 3 probation and a GVI candidate at the time of this arrest.  A probation administrative warrant was completed regarding this arrest.  It should be noted that Banks was the victim of a shooting on 6/23/23 in the area of 10th and Pine Streets.  Additionally, Banks is known to be a member of “Team A” (MGS).

On Tuesday October 17, 2023, 16C (Smagala/Franzone) responded to 4th and Dupont St regarding a motor vehicle
collision. Wilcom advised responding units that one of the individuals involved in the accident was armed with a gun and threatened
the operator of the vehicle that was not at fault. Upon their arrival, William Green BM 11/09/1977 was quickly identified as the
individual armed with a firearm and placed into custody. 16C located a black in color handgun in Green’s waistband (Springfield
XD-9, Serial #BY433306, loaded with thirteen (13) 9mm luger rounds in the magazine). The Victim stated that the spouse of the
striking vehicle responded to the scene and threatened him with the firearm for not exchanging information prior to police arrival. A
NCIC check for the firearm was met with negative results. Green was charged with Aggravated menacing and Carrying a Concealed
Deadly Weapon.

On April 20, 2024 at approximately 2111 hours, (1) shot spotter notification was received for (1) one round in the
area of 1204 West 4th Street. Officer Potts was flagged down by a subject who advised that her son fled into 308 North Harrison
Street and was armed with a firearm. Officer Potts notified Wilcom at which time assisting units arrived and conducted a surrounded
and call out to the subject. After several verbal commands, the Defendant identified as Shaka Lewis BM 01/06/1988, exited the
residence and was taken into custody by Cpl. O’Connor. Officers responded into 308 Harrison Street and secured same.
After obtaining various statements regarding this incident, it is believed the defendant deployed approximately several rounds from a
moving vehicle in the direction of two unknown subjects walking in the 1200 block of west 4th Street. The defendant ultimately struck
a Toyota Tacoma bearing Delaware registration HP45651 in the front windshield (4) times owned by Victim 5 (Gibbs, Roderick
2/17/56). The defendant then followed Victim 1 who into 308 N. Harrison Street. The defendant then walked to the second floor of
the residence and placed a firearm to Victim 3 Cruz, Felix 12/10/52 head. It should be noted, the residence was occupied by Victim 1
Austin, Raheem 12/5/90, Victim 2 Austin, Tristan 6/12/13 and Victim 4 Austin Ester 2/16/50 at the time the defendant entered the
property. Victim 1 and Victim 4 were able to flee from the residence and met with officers. Victim 2 hid in the master bedroom
closet until the recovered by officers.
Officer B. Merced assisted with translation and obtained pertinent statements from the victims. A consent form was signed and a
search of the residence was conducted. Officers located a loaded 9mm Taurus G2C bearing serial ABJ917499 which contained (8)
rounds in the magazine (1) one round in the chamber. The firearm was checked and negative.
CID Bucksner as well as FSU were notified and responded to the incident location. FSU recovered (2) spent casing as well the
firearm and additional evidence regarding this investigation. The vehicle in which the defendant shot from was searched for casings
met with negative results. A shot spotter audit was requested to obtain clarification on how many rounds discharged. It should be
noted, Radio Supervisor Grimes reached out to Shot Spotter who advised the incident was updated from (1) round at approximately
2300 hours to (5) rounds. No audit update information was received. The defendant was transported to 94 Wilmington to be evaluated
per CAPES.
not in gunstat meeting reports

On Wednesday June 12th, 2024, CGIC Detectives were contacted by Sierra from City Watch in reference to a
suspicious person in the area of E 22nd St and N. Spruce St. Detectives reviewed the video surveillance and observed Shamar Wright
BM 03/29/2001 in the 700 block of E 22nd St displaying characteristics of an armed gunman. Detectives responded to the area with
the assistance of Officers Diaz and Mann while surveillance was kept on Shamar who was now sitting on a porch in the block. Upon
arrival into the block, Detectives were able to make contact with Shamar and take him into custody without incident. Shamar was
found to be in possession of a Black in color Canik TP-9 SF Elite 9mm handgun (S/N 21BH05901) which was loaded with 7 rounds
of ammunition in the magazine and 1 in the chamber. Shamar was interviewed regarding this incident however refused to cooperate.
A test fire form was submitted. NCIC inquiry on the firearm was conducted which was met with negative results. Shamar was
currently wanted out of the Wilmington Police Department, Delaware State Police and New Castle County Police in regards to
terroristic threatening along with 5 additional capiases. Safe Streets was notified regarding the arrest and an admin warrant was issued
by probation.

On Thursday June 2nd 1245 hours, Safe Streets Officers conducted a traffic stop in the area of 800 New Castle Ave
on a vehicle for speeding and disregarding a red light in the area of E. 4th & N. Church St. During the stop, officers made contact with
Peter Gaddis who gave a false name and provided officers with a Moorish Nation Passport. While making contact with Gaddis,
officers smelled marijuana coming from inside the vehicle. An NCIC inquiry revealed that the vehicle was unregistered and that
Gaddis did not have a valid license. Gaddis was ordered out of the vehicle and was found to be in possession of a PT III Millennium
G2 9mm handgun concealed inside of his waistband. During a search of the vehicle, officers located a small amount of marijuana (3.8
grams).
Gaddis was transported to Central where officers obtained his real name. A DELJIS inquiry determined that Gaddis is prohibited from
owning/possessing a firearm as a result of prior felony convictions. He was also wanted by NCC Family Court for Failure to Appear
child support hearing and by Newark Alderman Court for Failure to Pay suspended license.

On Tuesday October 24, 2023, while in the 300 block of W. 7th Street, Det. Schupp observed a handgun protruding
from the right front pants pocket of Christopher Williams BM 05/11/1989 who was then observed entering the 7th Street Deli located
at 307 W. 7th Street. Members of the Vice Unit stopped Williams without incident and recovered a loaded black in color Taurus G3C
9mm semi-automatic handgun (#AED271538). Williams was transported to Central and charged accordingly. An admin warrant
authored by Safe Streets. The firearm as well as the Test Fire Form was submitted to FSU for processing

On Friday September 23rd 0300 hours, officers were approached on a shots fired scene by the listed victim, Harris. Harris stated that he was having issues with his live in girlfriend (Adrian Moody, BFN, DOB 09/23/1991) at his listed residence and believes that she recently stole his firearm. Harris stated that he checked his usual storage spot for his firearm (9mm Smith & Wesson, unknown make, unknown serial #), but found that same was missing. Officers responded to 417 N. Church St and made contact was made with Moody, who denied all involvement and consented to a search or her person and property, which met with negative results. There was some belief that the shots fired incident in the 800 block of E. 4th Street (30-22-67034) was related due to the caliber and timing of same. No evidence could be located to corroborate these beliefs. Officers were dispatched back to the residence at 1816 for another domestic incident. Contact was made with Harris who advised that he found his missing firearm in a paper bag on the living room floor and advised that it was not there prior to Moody arriving at the residence. While speaking with Harris, officers observed that he had a firearm in his waistband. Officers took custody of the weapons and transported all parties to central pending further investigation. While at Central, Moody confessed to removing the firearm the previous evening and returning it today. Moody was charged with Theft of a Firearm and booked at Central. 30-22-067039

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On March 13, 2025, members of the DOCV executed a search warrant at 417 N. Church St, in reference to an ongoing drug investigation. Prior to the execution of the search warrant, officers observed Brandon Harris (11/14/1982) leave the residence at which time he was taken into custody. 
With the assistance of Safe Streets, members of DOCV were able to execute the search warrant, where Kevin Harris (07/22/1972) was also taken into custody without incident. As a result of the search, officers recovered 371 grams of Marijuana, packaging material, and a Black in color Smith and Wesson SD9 9mm (S/N: FXH9611) semi-auto handgun. Both suspects were charged accordingly.

On July 23, 2025, at approximately 0818 hours, Officer Stewart was dispatched to 1305 N. Broom Street in reference to a report of a person with a firearm. Upon arrival, Officer Stewart made contact with the victim/reporting party, Kobey Wesley. Wesley stated that he had found a cell phone earlier in the week at the CVS and decided to keep it. On the same date, Yusef Kallam-Crumpler returned to the CVS searching for his lost cell phone. The CVS store manager reviewed surveillance footage and observed Wesley retrieving the phone from the self-checkout counter, where it had been left by Crumpler. The manager then provided Crumpler with a still image of Wesley taken from the footage. Using GPS tracking, Crumpler located Wesley in the 1300 block of Broom Street and confronted him regarding the phone. During the confrontation, Crumpler brandished a firearm and pointed it at Wesley, demanding the return of his phone. Crumpler remained on scene until officers arrived. Following a brief investigation, he was taken into custody and charged with aggravated menacing. The firearm, a Shadow Systems CR920 9mm (SN: S028340), was seized and submitted into evidence.

On Monday June 26th 1233 hours, Gun Intelligence Investigators Moses and Lerro were on proactive patrol in the
area of 7th and Washington Street when they observed a subject displaying characteristics of an armed gunman. Investigators exited
their unmarked police vehicle and attempted to make contact with the subject. The subject quickly attempted to avoid Investigators by
entering into 408 W. 7th Street, however the door was secured. Investigators made contact with the subject who was identified as
(Ja’vonte Waters BM 03/28/2004). The defendant briefly resisted arrest, but was taken into custody without further incident.
Investigators conducted a search on the defendant and located a black in color Smith & Wesson M&P .380 handgun SN# NCL125)
containing 1 round in the chamber and 4 rounds in the magazine. Additionally, Investigators located 61 grams of marijuana and
$1238 USC on the defendant’s person. Investigators notified probation and parole and conducted an Administrative Search on the
defendant’s residence met with negative results. Probation also assisted and applied an Admin Warrant. The Firearm was checked
locally and NCIC and Negative.

On September 2nd at approximately 0045 hours, Officers Gledhill, Michael Davis, and Zachary Davis responded to
1950 Seneca Road for a person with a gun complaint. The reporting person advised that a female was in the block waiving a firearm around and causing a disturbance. It is believed that the defendant is the ex-girlfriend of RP’s current boyfriend. Arriving officers made contact with the defendant, Zequina Harrison BF 03/23/1991 who was placed into custody. Officers recovered a Glock 19 9mm handgun (#AGCL844) loaded with 6 rounds of ammunition in the magazine and 1 round in the chamber. The firearm was recovered from a black bag inside of Harrison’s vehicle along with a marijuana blunt located in plain view in the front cup holder of the vehicle. An NCIC inquiry on the firearm determined that the gun was not reported stolen at the time of this incident. The firearm was submitted into evidence and a Test Fire Request Form was submitted to FSU.

During the month of July 2024, CGIC initiated a firearm investigation into Syncere Money (02/10/2007), Amir Carr-Powell (07/16/2005), and Naim Benson (03/22/2006), in reference to them being in possession of multiple firearms. Detectives applied for and were granted search warrants for 5 Buena Vista St and 227 W 26th St.

On July 25th, 2024 members of CGIC, DOCV, Safe Streets and Probation established surveillance on 5 Buena Vista in reference to the search warrant. During this time members of CGIC and Juvenile Probation responded to 227 W 26th St in reference Naim Benson who was on GPS and inside the residence. While attempting to make contact with the occupants of the residence, Benson fled out the rear of the property and cut off his GPS. An area canvas and K9 track was conducted but met with negative results. 
A search of the residence was conducted at which point detectives located and recovered one black in color Glock 19 9mm (S/N BYUF245), 1 black in color magazine containing 14 rounds of ammunition, 1 loose round of 9mm ammunition, and one black in color extended magazine.  Naim Benson was arrested on 07/30/24 after fleeing on foot from 227 W 26th. 
At approximately 1500 hours, Syncere Money was observed exiting the residence and standing on the front porch.  While Syncere was standing out front Detectives were able to make contact with him at which point he was detained.  With the assistance of DOCV, Safe Streets and Probation detectives executed the search warrant for 5 Buena Vista.  During a search of the residence, Detectives located and recovered the following: 
•	Black and Green in color AK-47 Rifle (No S/N)
•	Black and Gray in color Polymer 80 loaded with 12 rounds of 9mm ammunition
•	One (1) rifle magazine containing 24 rounds of 7.62 X 39 ammunition
•	Clothing 
•	Misc. paperwork belonging to Syncere

defendant_name: Kyair, Keys; Parham, Walike, Richards, Markel
case_status:
D1: Resolved 
D2: Resolved
D3: Resolved

case_summary:
On Tuesday January 2, 2024 at approximately 2155 hours officers were dispatched to 2207 Pyle Street in regards to an aggravated menacing.  Upon arrival they met with the victim (Serina Cannon) who fled the residence and advised the suspect was still inside armed with a handgun.  She further advised that her (2) two children ages 16 and 10 were also inside the residence.

Serina advised she and the suspect (Remington Steele BM 02/13/1987) engaged in a verbal argument earlier today and during same, the suspect pointed a small black in color handgun at her while threatening to kill her.  During this time, the victim was able to escape and flee the residence; however she left her 16 year old daughter and 10 year old son behind inside the residence. Serina also advised the suspect had been heavily drinking all day long, and was refusing to let the children leave the residence.  
 
After approximately (15) fifteen minutes of verbal commands the suspect called the victim, who was outside with officers, and asked that the officers leave.  At this point M/Cpl. Marino took the victim’s phone and engaged the suspect in conversation.  Over the course of the next (30) thirty minutes Marino talked with the suspect, built a rapport with him using the theme of family, and eventually convinced the suspect to surrender and exit the residence.  The suspect exited the residence and was placed into custody without incident.  

Both children exited the residence and were debriefed.  The oldest child (Omecca Steele BF 05/24/07) was carrying a large purse when she exited.  The purse was searched for any evidence at which point (2) two firearms were located inside.  The first was a small black in color Ruger 9mm handgun, and the second was a large silver in color Smith & Wesson .357 revolver. Neither gun was listed as stolen.  The second child to exit the residence (Bashir Steele BM 11/12/13) was not concealing any items on his person.

A consent to search the residence was obtained from the victim/wife for the residence.  A small bag located in the living room was found to have (15) fifteen Magpul PMAGs inside, all with (30) thirty round capacity.  All of the PMAGs were empty and still in their plastic wrapping.  They all appeared to be old as the plastic wrapping had a large amount of dust on the exterior.  No other items of evidentiary value were located.  

Both children were turned over family members.  A pre-arrest intake is being conducted for guidance relating to the juvenile concealing the (2) two firearms in her purse.  The suspect was transported to central.

time_to_recovery:
Starquest Guns: Same day
First State Gun: 30

defendant_name: Frank Butts, Dwayne Woodhouse, Sean Smith
case_summary:
In response to recent acts of violence in District 13, Det. Cuadrado initiated a drug investigation into several subjects
selling Crack Cocaine from 112 E. 23rd Street, Wilmington, DE. On Tuesday September 14th 1347 hours, surveillance was established
on 112 E. 23rd Street, surveillance observed approximately 9 individuals in front of the residence. Members of the Vice Unit, SCU,
K9, & USD responded to the location, detained all the subjects, and executed the search warrant without incident. During a search of
the residence, all the items seized were found to belong to Frank Butts and Dwayne Woodhouse.
• Mossberg MC1 SC 9mm semi-automatic handgun, serial # obliterated, loaded with a total of 7 rounds of 9mm ammo.
• Springfield XDS .45 ACP semi-automatic handgun, serial # S3180366, (29N), loaded with a total of 5 rounds of .45
caliber ammunition.
• 26.5 grams of Crack Cocaine.
• .548 grams of Heroin stamped “SUSUKI & EZPASS”.
• Various types of ammunition and handgun magazines.
• $305.00 USC.
• Drug Paraphernalia.
While on scene Officer Lero observed a Black 2014 Nissan Rogue DE PC308021 (registered to Sean Smith) parked in front of the
residence. Officers were able to see in plain sight a Taurus PT III G2C 9mm handgun serial # ABC401911, (29N), loaded with a
total of 11 rounds of 9mm ammunition. The vehicle was transported to central where a search warrant was authored and obtained.
Smith was found in possession of the keys to the vehicle and .5 grams of marijuana.
All three firearms and Test Fire Forms were submitted to FSU for processing. Both firearms with serial numbers were negative for
warrants. DNA was obtained from all defendants. All defendants are convicted felons.

defendant_name: Jones, Kyaire; Cooke, William; Lowman, Sharif
case_status:
D1: Resolved 
D2: Resolved

case_summary:
During the month of June, Det. Rosaio initiated an investigation into Crack Cocaine sales by Kyaire Jones and
William Cooke from 612 N. Tatnall Street, Wilmington, DE. Additional information was obtained that both subjects possibly possessed
four handguns.
On this date, during the course of surveillance, William Cooke was observed entering a vehicle and leaving the area. While operating
the vehicle, William Cooke was observed pointing a handgun out of the vehicle window. The vehicle was followed to the 1300 block of
Linden Street where it parked. Members of the Vice Unit with the assistance of CGIC conducted a Felony vehicle stop and took all
occupants into custody without incident, the occupants and vehicle were transported to Central. It should be noted that this stop was
conducted in the presence of family members.
Surveillance was maintained on the residence, shortly after the initial arrest, Kyaire Jones and Sharif Lowman were observed exiting
the residence with a bag and walking away. Members of CGIC attempted to stop Kyaire Jones and Sharif Lowman at 8th & Tatnall
Street. Upon approach Kyaire Jones fled from officers and after a brief foot pursuit was taken into custody. Kyaire Jones was found to
have on his person the listed Glock Gen 5 (#BUCY515) with a full auto selector switch and a large quantity of Crack Cocaine. Sharif
Lowman was found to have on his person the listed Stoeger 9mm (#T6429-22Y08505).
Through the course of this investigation, a search warrant was authored and obtained for 612 N. Tatnall Street and the vehicle William
Cooke was operating. The search warrant was executed on the residence without incident, and the Ruger LCP (#371538268), additional
drugs, and drug paraphernalia were located. L&I contacted and responded regarding the conditions of the residence. A search warrant
was executed on the vehicle, the handgun observed during surveillance was found to be a CO2 pellet gun, additional drugs and
paraphernalia were also recovered.
not in gunstat meeting reports

defendant_name: Eriq Morrison, Dwayne Arnold, Isaiah Johnson
case_summary: not in gunstat meeting reports

On September 17, 2025, at approximately 1541 hours, WPD responded to an incident of shots fired in the area of 200 W.
35th Street (30-25-66569). During the investigation, officers located .45 and .380 caliber shell casings. Witnesses on scene advised they
observed two subjects flee into 223 W. 35th St, after the shots fired. Members of Safe Streets utilized GPS and observed Dhossan Whyte
(12/19/2009) to be in the area at the time the Shot Spotter notification, and currently wanted on a VOP capias. Safe Streets contacted
Juvenile Probation who advised Whyte’s GPS was putting him in 223 W. 23rd Street, which is the listed residence of another juvenile
probationer, Darren Bailey (12/13/2006).
Upon arrival, Safe Streets coordinated with patrol, to locate and detain Bailey and Whyte without incident inside the residence. Bailey was
found to be in possession of a concealed Cobra CA-380 .380 caliber (SN#CPO65844) handgun, with no ammunition. Officers obtained
consent to search the residence, however, no additional evidence was located. Bailey and Whyte (VOP) were transported to Central
charged accordingly

On October 7, 2025, at approximately 1428 hours, Officers received information regarding a suspicious person at the
intersection of W. 5th and N. Madison St. Officers observed Yah-Cin Miller (01/17/2011) activity arguing with another individual. When
officers approached the individuals and attempted to make contact, Miller fled on foot. He continued into an alley, where he was finally
able to be apprehended. After back tracking Miller’s flight path, officers located a Glock 42 .380 (SN#AGKS441) handgun was located in
the rear yard of 605 W. 5th St. Miller was taken back to Central and charged accordingly. DNA was also taken as part of the investigation.

On Wednesday August 17th 2005 hours, Safe Streets received information from a past proven and reliable
confidential informant regarding a subject armed with a firearm in the area of 7th and Tatnall Street. Safe Streets responded to the area
and observed Stinson matching the description provided by the informant. Officers conducted a stop of Stinson and found him in
possession of a loaded Beretta .22 caliber firearm and (40 grams) of marijuana. Stinson was also found to be wanted out of the New
Castle County Superior Court for failure to appear for a case review regarding a PWID charge stemming from an arrest on 03/04/22.

On Friday May 10th, 2024, 13 Adam (Mann/Diaz) responded to 23rd/Market Streets to conduct a directed patrol.
When they arrived, they observed a group loitering in front of a closed store (2230 North Market Street). The officers exited their car
and began a foot patrol, at which time most of the group walked away. Kyaire Harris BM 12/27/2004 remained seated on the steps
and exhibited the characteristics of an armed subject. The officers conducted a pedestrian stop and located a Kel Tec P11 9mm
(#13418) firearm concealed in Mr. Harris’s pants. Harris was taken into custody and charged accordingly

On Tuesday May 2nd 0109 hours, C Platoon Officer Dongbetor was proactively patrolling in the 800 block of
Delaware Avenue when he observed five black male juveniles acting suspiciously. Contact was made with Amir Morris BM
03/21/2007, Trae King BM 09/26/2005, Markeed Boyd BM 07/26/08, Jummah El BM 01/09/08 and Kymani Roberts BM 07/15/05.
Amir Morris gave a false name and was found to be in possession of a loaded Smith & Wesson 9mm handgun (#AA316122) which
was located in his jacket pocket. Morris was taken into custody and charged accordingly. Trae King was charged with a curfew
violation. Boyd, El and Roberts were checked out and sent on their way.

On Thursday June 20th 1620 hours, Gun Intelligence Investigators responded to a shooting incident on Maryland
Avenue to provide assistance. When the scene was secured and no additional information was available, Gun Intelligence
Investigators proactively patrolled the 200 block of S. Harrison Street. While on proactive patrol, Investigators observed three (3)
subjects sitting on the steps of 225 S. Harrison St loitering. Investigators attempted to make contact with the subjects, however the
defendant Tyree Anderson BM 10/05/2001 immediately stood up and began fleeing on foot in the opposite direction of Investigators.
While fleeing, the defendant was observed attempting to remove a cross body satchel from across his chest. After a brief foot pursuit,
Investigators observed the defendant discard the satchel over a fence and into the rear yard of 10 S. Harrison Street. Investigators were
able to immediately recover the satchel as well as locate and take the defendant into custody without incident. Located inside the
satchel was a black in color H & R Inc. .22 caliber Revolver handgun containing 6 live 22 caliber rounds in the cylinder
(#AZ029366). The defendant’s DNA was retrieved and tagged into evidence. A test fire request was completed.

On Monday, December 1, 2025, CGIC Investigators were granted a search warrant at 848 Bennett St, after
detectives were made aware a social media video, in which Naji Armstrong (09/26/2007) was seen to be in possession of two firearms. Surveillance was established by CGIC, as well as members of DOCV. At approximately 1435 hours, Armstrong was observed exiting the residence of 848 Bennett St. Armstrong was placed into custody without incident at the intersection
of 7th and Spruce. Investigations then executed the search warrant, where they were able to locate a loaded tan in color Glock 19 9mm (SN#CEBD868) handgun, with a black laser attachment. Additionally, investigations located a black in color Polymer 80 PFC9 9mm (No SN) handgun, with a laser attachment and loaded with 17 rounds of 9mm ammunition. Armstrong was transported to Central and charged accordingly.

On Friday April 22nd 1620 hours, ACU were in the 2800 block of N. Market St when they observed Marvin Barefield acting suspiciously. Barefield immediately entered a store within the block after observing offices approaching. SCU officers conducted an approach on Barefield who was no longer in possession of a satchel which he was previously observed carrying prior to entering the store. Officers observed Barefield speaking with Shavanna Truitt who was now in possession of the satchel. Officers spoke with Truitt who advised that there was a firearm inside the satchel. Officers then searched same and located a loaded Glock 43 9mm which contained 6 rounds in the magazine and 1 in the chamber, an additional magazine containing 6 rounds, and (140) oxycodone pills.
SCU officers observed Barefield to possess keys to a vehicle which smelled like an unburnt odor of marijuana. A search of the vehicle was conducted where a purse was located in the back seat containing a SCCY CPX-2 9mm firearm loaded with (11) 9mm rounds in the magazine. On the front passenger floor board, officers observed a black bag which contained a magazine drum containing (31) 9mm rounds. (207) MDMA pills, (330.14) grams Marijuana, an assortment of (37) Marijuana edibles, (9) prepackaged marijuana cigars, and (2) marijuana vape pens were located.

case_status: Disposition not yet listed in Gunstat 2025 spreadsheet (as of 5/20/25 update)
case_summary:
On Tuesday, June 17, 2025, CGIC detectives, along with Det. Macnamara, Det. Cannon, and Cpl Rogers were working the 29P overtime initiative, when they observed Edward Robinson in the 2700 block of N. West St, walking away from a black n color pickup truck. Detectives were aware Robinson was currently wanted on a Violation of Probation, he has also been seen posting on social media, while in possession of a black in color firearm.
Detectives continued towards Robinson, when he immediately noticed the officers and began to flee. Officers exited their vehicles and pursued Robinson into an alley, where he was taken into custody. While officers were pursuing Robinson, K9 Williams made contact with the occupants of the pickup truck, the subjects were known to be Khalil Rodriguez-Fitzgerald, Brian Palmer (04/08/2008), Sincere Johnson, and Dhossan Whyte. The subjects were detailed pending the investigation. During this time Rodriguez-Fitzgerald consented to a search of the vehicle at which time officers located and recovered a black in color Glock 34 9mm (S/N: BHXR974) handgun loaded with 30 rounds of ammunition, underneath the front passenger seat. While on scene, Palmer advised officers the located firearm was his.
E. Robinson, Rodriguez-Fitzgerald, Palmer, Whyte, Johnson, Ahmaijae Robinson, and Joseph Carter were transported to Central, along with the evidence. DNA were taken from Rodriguez-Fitzgerald, Whyte, and Johnson.

On January 18, 2025, at approximately 0012 hours, WPD officers were dispatched and responded to the area of D Street and Townsend Place in reference to an armed robbery complaint (30-25-004187). Officers made contact with the victim, John Jordan (10/23/1967) who advised he was a delivery driver for Pete’s Pizza and had responded to 739 Townsend Place. While waiting in front of the residence, he was approached by two black male suspects wearing all black with ski masks and both displaying handguns. Jordan’s keys, wallet and cell phone were taken and both suspects ran to the victim’s vehicle 2015 black Subaru Forester (DE Temp Tag XQ566833) and fled out of sight.
A brief time later, Officer Gula observed the vehicle travelling on Vandever Ave towards Claymont Street. As Gula was waiting for assisting officers to respond to his location the vehicle fled from him and a vehicle pursuit was initiated. The vehicle ultimately crashed and two defendants were observed fleeing from the vehicle on foot. They were then taken into custody and identified as Markeed Boyd (07/26/2008) and Brian Streater (12/28/2007).
Boyd was located in the rear of 805 Morrow Street and a black Keltec P32 .32 caliber handgun (S/N #121932) loaded with 5 rounds was found in close proximity. Streater was located in front of 710 North Madison Street. An area search was conducted by assisting officers at which time a black Glock 43x 9mm handgun (S/N #CBWN058) loaded with 12 rounds was located on the sidewalk near the intersection of West 8th and Windsor Streets. The vehicle was towed to central to be processed by FSU.

On February 25, 2025, at approximately 1517 hours, members of Safe Streets were in the 300 block of East. 23rd St when they observed Cardea Hollis (12/29/2010) acting suspiciously and displaying characteristics of an armed gunman. Officers noticed Hollis to be holding his left arm tightly against the left side of his body, in addition, he quickly began to change his direction in an attempt to allude officers. Members of Safe Streets attempted to stop Hollis, who immediately fled on foot. With the assistance of Officers Gervasi and Holland, Hollis was taken into custody in the 100 block of East 24th St, as well as a Ruger P95 9mm (S/N: #31832481) handgun loaded with one round in the chamber and 8 rounds in the magazine, which was in Hollis’ left pocket. Upon being taken into custody, he dropped the firearm next to his person. Hollis and the firearm were transported to Central. It should be noted that Hollis was listed as “wanted” due to being a reported runaway juvenile.

On September 10th, 2024, at 1931 hours, Officers were in the area of West 2nd and North Franklin on a directed patrol. At this time, officers observed James Hall (01/06/1988) walking north in the 100 block of North Franklin Street. Hall began to exhibit the characteristics of a person concealing a firearm. Once Hall noticed the officers, he turned away, shielding himself and began walking the opposite direction. He continued to keep his left arm rigidly pressed against his fanny pack, is maintained in the same postion, as if he were attempting to conceal an object and keep it from moving. Hall repeated looked over his shoulder as he was attempting to place distance between himself and the officers. They then attempted to conduct a pedestrian stop, but Hall fled. After a short pursuit, officers apprehended him and recovered a gun that had been concealed in a crossbody-style bag. The firearm was a red Smith & Wesson M&P (serial #HSF4548), loaded with 12 rounds in the magazine and one in the chamber.

On Friday April 8th 1228 hours, SCU were in the 100 block of E 24th St when they observed several subjects
loitering on the sidewalk. SCU officers approached the subjects and specifically made contact with the defendant (James McDougal)
who refused to identify himself. SCU officers observed the defendant to have a bulge in his waistband and conducted a pat down.
Located inside the defendant’s waistband was a 9mm SCCY CPX-2 firearm which contained (10) rounds in the magazine.

On September 24th, 2024 CGIC initiated an investigation into Naseer Bullock (02/01/2007) after being contacted by Cpl Mann in reference to an aggravated menacing/terroristic threatening which occurred in the unit block of W 36th St. Cpl Mann responded to a complaint of a Person with a Gun in the area of the Pal Center. During his initial investigation, Cpl Mann made contact with the victims in this incident who advised of an altercation which occurred in the unit block of W 36th St during which time a suspect by the name of ‘Naz’ produced a firearm an threatened to ‘air it out’. During Cpl Mann’s initial investigation he was able to identify Naseer Bullock as a person of interest in this incident. 
 As a result of the investigation, CGIC detectives applied for and were granted a search warrant for 30 W 36th St. On September 26th, CGIC along with Cpl Mann and Juvenile probation responded to 30 W 36th St and made contact with Naseer Bullock, Drea Dimatteo (10/13/2003) and Shawn Cooper (05/25/1982) at which point detectives executed the search warrant. 
 During a search of the residence, Detectives located and recovered one black in color Beretta APX 9mm (SN #A156480X). While interviewing the occupants, Detectives were able to determine that Naseer has access to a Grey in color Volkswagen Passat which was parked out front. Detectives subsequently had the vehicle towed to Central where a search warrant was executed. During a search of the vehicle, Detectives located and recovered a black and grey in color Taurus G3C 9mm firearm (SN #ACH157880) loaded with a total of 8 rounds of 9mm ammunition.

On Thursday November 3rd 1847 hours, SCU Investigators were in the 2200 block of West Street when they
observed the defendant Vasquez, Salvador (BM 03/11/1998) walking on foot acting suspiciously. Upon the defendant observing the
Street Crimes vehicle, the defendant quickly walked onto the porch of 2200 West Street. Street Crimes officers attempted to make
contact with the defendant, however he exited off the porch and fled on foot. While fleeing, the defendant was observed displaying
characteristics of an armed gunman and was ultimately taken into custody on a rear porch of 2301 Tatnall Street. Upon conducting an
area canvass of the porch, Officers located a loaded (RUGER P95 9mm Semi-Automatic Firearm containing 1 live round in the
chamber and (10) 9mm rounds in the magazine 1 foot away from where the defendant was taken into custody. The serial # 318-
12885 was checked locally and NCIC and found to be Negative. The defendant is a (Run It up Gang Member) who is known to
frequent the Riverside area. Street Crimes Officers drafted a DNA search warrant and same was obtained. Safe Streets were notified to
assist with an Admin Search

On Friday April 19, 2024 at approximately 1734 hours, Officers responded to 609 E. 22nd Street in reference to a Domestic incident where a subject was armed with a firearm. Upon arrival, officers met with victim Jameka Owens BF 04/26/82 who advised that she was involved in a verbal altercation with the defendant (Arik Tkalich WM 09/14/1990) who struck her in the back of the head. After the assault, the defendant exited the residence. While leaving, the defendant removed a firearm from his waistband and threatened to kill the victim. The victim advised she dialed 911 and observed the defendant enter 616 E. 22nd Street. Assisting Officers arrived on scene and established a perimeter around the residence. CMTT was notified and Detective Moses implemented a plan of action which was executed flawlessly enabling the use of the (Two way Duplexer) which was deployed into the residence which allowed Cpl. Wiggins to speak with the defendant. After brief communication with the defendant, Cpl. Wiggins was able to persuade the defendant to exit the residence and was taken into custody without incident. A search of the residence resulted in the recovery of a tan and black Taurus 9mm Millennium firearm (#T1080624) which contained (13) 9mm rounds. The firearm was found to be stolen out of NCCPD on 10/16/15 (32-15-104995). The victim provided an additional extended magazine which contained 30 live rounds believed to be the defendant’s. Approximately 30 bags of heroin was also located and tagged as found property.

On December 25, 2024, at approximately 2312 hours, Officers Hutt and Jacobs responded to 125 North Market St (Over The Border Tacos) in reference to a complaint of terroristic threatening. Officers were able to review the business’ surveillance footage which revealed the defendant, Van Swafford (06/25/2001), displaying a firearm from his waistband during a verbal argument with victim, Charles Hopkins (10/25/1978), over a parking spot. Officers were able to make contact with Hopkins, who confirmed the series of events. Swafford was located on scene by officers, and a search incident revealed the Smith and Wesson M&P Pro Series 9mm (S/N #HPH8763), containing 15 rounds of ammunition, was found on his person. Swafford was taken into custody and charged accordingly.

On December 2, 2024 at approximately 1204 hours, Officer Hutt responded to a two-vehicle collision at the intersection of W. 2nd & N. Adams Street. Upon arrival, Officer Hutt made contact with Emmanuel Whitfield BM 11/16/2000 who was the driver and sole occupant of the striking vehicle. As a result of the collision, Whitfield’s vehicle was rendered inoperable and required towing from the scene. Prior to the tow, Officer Hutt conducted a standard vehicle inventory, during which time he observed the end (handle) of what appeared to be a firearm in the driver-side door cup holder, partially covered by a yellow envelope. Whitfield was questioned about the object at which point he advised the officer that it was a firearm. The firearm was a loaded 38SPL 375 Magnum Revolver (#AEK801467). Whitfield was transported to Wilmington Hospital for a medical evaluation due to injuries sustained in the collision. Following his discharge from the hospital, he was transported to Central and charged accordingly.

On October 4, 2025, at approximately 2331 hours, Officer R. Brown was in the area of 100 N. Vanburen St, when he
observed a Chevrolet Camaro (DE 476256) traveling without its headlights on. At this time a traffic stop was conducted, and made contact
with driver, Heriberto Pedrozo-Castanon (01/11/2003). The driver revealed the vehicle’s registration could not be produced, and has
expired insurance. Pedrozo-Castanon stated he had a firearm on his person but did not possess a conceal carry permit. He was removed
from the vehicle, and officers located a Glock 48 9mm (SN # CBXY179US) handgun, loaded with eight rounds of ammunition
concealed in the front waistband. In addition, Pedrozo-Castanon also had an extended magazine in his pocket, containing eighteen rounds.
A search warrant was authored and executed on the vehicle, where officers located a black in color drum magazine containing twelve
9mm rounds.
Pedrozo-Castanon was charged accordingly.

On Friday May 3, 2024 at approximately 1336 hours, 212 Cpl. Keith Johnson executed a JP20 Search Warrant at
1208 Oak St in reference to an ongoing OHV Investigation. Information had been received that Jacob Halsey WM 09/26/2000 was
operating his OHV with a concealed firearm on multiple occasions. During this search warrant execution, a 2024 blue Yamaha
YZ250, a Glock 34 9mm firearm (#BZSN330), 9mm ammunition, and other OHV accessories were seized. Halsey was also able to be
linked back to prior OHV investigations (30-24-029891, 30-24-031486, 30-24-032096) and was cited in reference to all three.
